description:
Come to this restaurant if you want to experience a real umma's (Korean mom's) cooking. It's a one-woman show and she locks the door when she can't handle any more customers. If you run into this situation, you can wait outside and she'll start letting people in again when she's ready. I gotta respect that attitude. 

We ordered a seafood bibimbap $16.95, a beef bibimbap $14.95, and a seafood tofu soup $11.95. The bibimbaps were delicious, but I probably wouldn't order the tofu soup again. You couldn't see any pieces of seafood in it, and there wasn't very much quantity. Maybe I'd get a kimchi stew instead?

A bottle of beer is $6 and is enormous about equal to two normal bottles of beer. This is the best value on the menu. 

Going with the theme, this is a homestyle place, so you get some typical homestyle banchan. If you want excitement and ambiance, go somewhere else. If you want comfort Korean, come to Um Ma Son.
author: Julia C.

description:
The food was amazing here! Tonight was my first time trying this place out and I must say, it is a good go to spot for authentic Korean meal. It really reminds me of my mom's home cooked meals!

Will be coming back again~
author: Kelsey T.

description:
This place is amazing! It's a one woman snow in here but her efforts don't go unnoticed!

My friend who grew up in and lived for some years as an adult in Korea brought me here for the first time. So to say it's been heavily vetted is an understatement. 

The beginning plates are authentic and the kimchi is phenomenal. 

The meals are large servings and can easily be split. They are all so delicious, so you may have a hard time choosing. 

The only thing to note is that you may have to work a little harder to get your bill on a busy night but believe me, you won't mind. The owner will check on you through out the meal and she has a wonderful Grandma type of personality. 

You won't be disappointed!!
author: Milan G.

description:
So today I went there with a friend at around 6:30, and this sweet lady welcomed us to our seats! She was so sweet and let us take our time when ordering. 
She took our orders and then walked into the kitchen, and what we realized is that she was also the one who was cooking! The food did not even take very long, but it was also not busy when we were there. 
The food was delicious! My favorite was the seafood tofu soup, but it was not filled with lots of seafood which I personally like better! The sides were all good, I was so stuffed after! 
We also probably spent a good twenty minutes just talking so I really enjoyed how she didn't rush us to leave. Can't wait to come back!
author: Linda N.

description:
Decent food and flexible hours! My boyfriend and I came here at 11:30 pm and demolished a plate of their bulgogi. The meal came with kimchi, potatoes, cucumbers, and sprouts as banchan. The bulgogi was delicious and tender, and very flavorful after the marinating. 

The hosts were very hospitable despite the lateness of the hour. Tea was complimentary with the food. That being said, a plate of bulgogi was $20, which seemed a little pricey to me, but hey it's SF so I can't be too bothered I suppose.
author: Allison T.

description: Cutest hole in the wall Korean joint run by a Korean women who I'm pretty sure runs the whole place by herself. Everything we ordered was amazing. Japchae, don bu, rice cakes and bulgogi
author: Teresa W.

description: There's a reason this place is called "Mom's Hands" in Korean. I honestly felt like I was eating food made by my mom. The food is delicious and the service is wonderful. Other Korean restaurants around the area are often really crowded and loud; I felt so comfortable and cozy at this spot, like I was having dinner at home! Will definitely be back again.
author: Alice W.

description: This place is a gem! The owner cooked all the food herself and you can tell it was made with love. It felt like I was invited to her home and she was feeding her guests. Absolutely delicious. Highly recommend.
author: Sarah S.

description: The owner, she is really nice and the food is the best Korean food in town. Try Kimchi pancake and spicy beef noodle(yook gae tang?)
author: Mac C.

description:
When was the last time you had Korean food where the cashier was also the owner and the chef?! Seriously, this umma is amazing.

Came for a late night dinner after a concert in the city, and sis and I wanted some hearty Asian food since it was rainy and around 10PM in the evening. Thank goodness for yelp's guidance to Um Ma Son in Richmond. We were the only other group that went in to eat--a table of four was finishing up when we went in. We were immediately served hot barley tea and given banchan once we placed our orders--seafood pancake to share, beef glass noodles for sis, and seafood tofu soup for me. 

Everything came out super fast considering that this smiley Korean g-ma was the only one working all of the positions! Food was so delicious, and all of the banchan were yummy. We asked her for more of a select banchan, and she smiled and said something in Korean and brought it out. The food was not oily, like most seafood pancakes are, and the flavors were SO prominent. Diners who care a lot about ambiance and the "lewk" of a place might be turned off by how basic and lacking Um Ma Son is. But if you grew up eating in low-key places like this, you'd agree with me that aesthetic means nothing in a Korean spot. This place accepts card, and there are restrooms in the back.

The warm and no frills space, comforting quality food, and basic aesthetic reminded me of how great simplicity and good food should be more than enough to keep customers like me happy. It's quiet and music-less, so it's great for a quiet dinner or smaller groups. I will definitely come back to Um Ma Son for delicious and worthy Korean tofu soup and dishes like seafood pancake!
author: Jodi H.

description:
Food = good. 

Hae mul pa jun (seafood pancake) = Delicious. Although if you're looking for crisp...this wasn't very crispy but great in flavor. $13.95, small. (There's a large size and I'm not sure I want to know.)

Dae gee bul go ki (spicy pork) = Epic. Melt-in- your- mouth good, layers of flavor. $20.95.

Kim chee duk bok um (kimchee rice cake with pork) = The best I've had in a while. Chewy but tender, and the sauce was delicious.  The pork pieces were addicting. $15.95.

Jop chae (yam noodles with beef and vegetables) = not my favorite. It was more greasy than I'm used to. $14.95.

Portions = hearty. 1 dish is more than enough for two people, and we (read: I) ordered 4 items for the two of us. 

Service = friendly and attentive. Definitely a one-woman shop--she takes your order, cooks, serves and all with a smile!

Prices = moderate. Dinner for two (with plenty of leftovers) came out to $73.00.

Plan to come back...with more people!
author: Fannie S.

description:
Service was top notch, shout out to the one woman running the whole restaurant by herself! The food itself was alright. 

Was craving hot tofu soup after freezing on the beach, and my friend recommended this place. It was surprisingly open late and had prices equivalent to korean mom and pop shop's in Santa Clara. I always expect prices of things in SF to be super inflated lol. Most of us ordered the beef tofu soup in spicy, which she cranked out really fast. The food actually came before our side dishes. Which by the way were really yummy, I've never had fishcake that good before and the potato was really flavorful too. I found the soup to be a little watery and not as filling as other places. It was also a little hard to flag her down for side and water refills but it was understandable because another party of 5 came in. Another con was that she didn't give us change... but we meant to tip her $15 anyway so I guess it doesn't matter. 

Decor here is really cute! It's a nice homey light blue color everywhere, and the bathroom was pretty tidy too
author: Nicolette E.

description: Im not sure how or when we discovered this cozy spot but it has become our to-go date night spot when we want some delicious quality authentic Korean food made and served by a sweet Korean grandma. She'd be your hostess, server, and chef!! It's an amazing one woman show especially if it's a busy night!! She tends to everybody's needs and the wait for the food is surprisingly not long or painful at all!! We've come so often that she will greet me with a huge smile and warm hug. We love supporting her business and we hope this spot gets the praise and recognition it deserves. We've tried more than half the dishes on the menu and nothing disappoints us!!
author: Carine M.

description: Went here with a party of 8, and had a great time. The most memorable part of this experience was that it feels like a restaurant run by a mother, and she took care of us like her children! She was the waitress and the cook, such a talented person. I later learned the name also means mother in Korean. Lovely experience. We ordered a lot of things on menu so I can't remember it all.
author: Ash A.

description:
We came in on a Sunday night around 10pm right after Outsidelands. Ordered the spicy tofu soup with meat. It lacked flavor and was bland for a spicy tofu soup. Wasn't spicy at all. The soup itself tasted like it was watered down. We also got the spicy tofu soup with seafood. It was pretty much the same problems we had with the soup. 

I give this place that extra star though for service. For handling the busy Outsidelands crowd between 3 ladies I was impressed. One was cooking in the kitchen while at the same time doing server duties. I give props to those 3 hardworking ladies for being able to serve as efficiently as they could.
author: Joyce D.

description:
Watched the woman who I think is the owner take orders, answer phone calls, bus tables, cook, serve the food, and bring drinks out ALL by herself and in a timely manner.

Since it was New Year's Day, I assume she thought it would be slow seeing as she was all alone. When I sat down and realized that she was working alone, I wasn't too concerned since it was just us two and another table of 6 and they were getting ready to leave. As we continued through the night, people started  trickling in-two tables of two and a party of 6. I was getting a bit nervous for her, but she didn't crack one bit. Everything from the food to the drinks came out right on time for everyone, just as it did for us when we arrived. I was so impressed.

the food- everything was amazing but very very very spicy. So be careful. The kimchi  fried rice paired perfectly with the spicy stir fry with shrimp and veggies. I forget the name of the soup but it was extremely spicy and also very delicious. Be sure to ask for a bottle of water, you'll need it.
author: Marcia S.

description: Great food. Excellent customer service. I am Korean and I took my mother who is a good judge of Korean food. And it is totally Korean Mother Approved. I had the Yook Hwe Jang and my mother had the Braised Short Ribs. Soooooo delicious.
author: Sandra O. N.

description:
We came here on a cold night craving Korean food. Clean and quiet family style restaurant. They gave us a good amount of side dish, we ordered a tofu soup, bibimbap, spicy squid, and spicy rice cake on ramen. 

My impression is that everything was very average, the spicy squid and spicy rice cake tasted the same probably because the sauce and seasoning were identical. The tofu soup was a little blend without much flavor. However, the owner gave us a complementary seafood pancake that actually tasted the best out of all the dishes we had that night! There were good amount of seafood and the pancake was crisp.

Will go to other Korean restaurant in the Richmond district, but if you are in a hurry, you can always get a table here easily and fill your stomach fast!
author: Karen C.

description: I loved so many things about this place! The sweet Korean lady, the quiet ambiance, and each item I ordered was excellent. Great banchan, seafood pancake was excellent and not greasy, soft tofu soup was perfection, and some of the best kalbi I've had.
author: Betsy H.

description:
four words: i love this woman. 

i do not usually write reviews but i am beyond amazed that this restaurant is ran by one person. she serves, she cooks, she cleans the dishes in between orders.

on top of that... the food is amazing! perhaps the best kimchi pancake that i've ever had. 

the wait for a table and for the food wasn't long, and that's crazy cause she's bussing tables, cooking, taking orders, etc. 

I ASPIRE TO BE THIS WOMAN.
author: Hester L.

description:
Realized I've been coming here for a long time with a tip over 5 years old, so this review is LONG overdue.

The Food
- Soups and stews are comfort food, kimchi jjigae is my favorite here
- Steamed mandoo is definitely good
- Stone pot Bibimbap
- Kimchi fried rice!  okay anything w her kimchi here is tasty

The Service
If it's slow, the service is so wonderful you feel like you're at someone's Mom's.  When it's a full house, well, you can walk up, do your best to remind / flag them down or speak Korean.  Remember it's a small restaurant though and not a chain, so the water has to boil.

The Restaurant
Groups are ok but couples have a better chance of seats during peak times.  I've seen ten people accommodated just fine though, but you may want to call ahead.  Parking is metered, street.  Restroom is a single.  And of course, save room for dessert or tea nearby! ;)

Lots of favorite times here which probably makes this place a spot when out in Richmond.  Now don't all of you go because then my late night spot will become too popular... :)
author: Jennifer Y.

description: This place is a gem. Menu makes you feel at home. Everything I've tried to date has been some of the best. From the humble bowl of rice cake soup to the Gal Bi Jim I have always been pleasantly surprised how much I've enjoyed every dish. This is a one woman (Mom) operation and she is serious about feeding you! Bring an appetite because in good Korean fashion the proportions tend to be large. Also, on a whole other review the Ban Chan is A+ in my book.
author: Zachary T.

description:
I love that you can come here to get a late bite to eat. When everything else in SF is closed, Um Ma Son's got you covered until midnight for some comfort Korean food!

I personally like the Go Ki Soon Du Bu (beef soft tofu soup). I asked for it mild and was a little taken aback at first because it was so red, but it really wasn't that spicy! Don't let the color scare you! Same with all the Ban Chan (side dishes)! They all look pretty red, but they're not excessively spicy. I don't have the largest appetite, and I was extremely full after I finished all my soup and most of the rice.

Prices are average for a Korean restaurant in SF (which is still kind of expensive in my eyes), so not too bad.

Service is also nice! The one woman working there is taking all the orders, and she's sweet and fast. :)

Overall, this place is great for late night cravings! But the food is still good and comparable to any other good Korean place in SF.
author: Rebecca T.

description: On the night that we went, this appeared to be a one woman show. The lady who runs this place was so friendly and motherly. The side dishes were delicious, and the stone pot rice was solid.
author: Long C.

description: Not sure why everyone raves about this place. I appreciate that it's a very nice, elderly Korean lady cooking, but I didn't find it as amazing as some of the other yelpers found it to be. I got a tofu soup, which tasted like hot kimchi water haha. Maybe I'm just spoiled with LAs koreatown food and my mom's own. Shout out to the super nice lady though, and the fact that they're open later than a lot of places!
author: Sandy K.

description:
I wish there was a Korean place that delivered close to home. When the roommate said he'd pick up food, we decided to try Um Ma Son. Ordered through GrubHub.

November 2013
*Banchan http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/um-ma-son-san-francisco#rzR4IP2jkgd18k5kJg_odQ
*Go ki soon du bu ($9.95) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/um-ma-son-san-francisco#RLPlWMPzCIYxNvghqu6zeQ
*Kal bi ($20.95) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/um-ma-son-san-francisco#c2T5PiSVttYL9xA45-_o5g
*Jo ki gu yi ($14.95) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/um-ma-son-san-francisco#RFtVOmCnl0dRQ8RmsNBPhQ
*Jop chae ($10.95) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/um-ma-son-san-francisco#dh5ql_P2mGlPvvAU8hlDUw
*Kim chee bok um bab ($10.95) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/um-ma-son-san-francisco#88fmRxMIaiNzI22NPuGjkg

We got a good amount of banchan. I especially liked the sprouts and fish cake. The food itself was solid. The soup was spicy. The short ribs smoky. The noodles had a good chew. The fish nicely grilled. The only thing that was just okay was the kimchee fried rice. I thought it was a little mushy and the egg a little overcooked. It didn't ooze onto the rice.

Nice mom and pop place. In fact, we recently ordered food from here again and enjoyed our meal. The only thing I noticed was they didn't seem to give us as much banchan this time. Still, their soondubu is good. The tofu is silky and it has a nice amount of spice. Just the way I like it!
author: Elena N.

description:
Great family owned Korean restaurant.  Bring a Korean and maybe earplugs? (TL;DR: Point at stuff on the menu and it gets loud)

Came here on a cold winter night looking for good ol' Korean Tofu Kimchi soup, it was around 9ish so it was hard to find something that was still open.  Luckily this places pretty much stays open as long as there's paying customers.  The owner is this little Korean lady that cooks, takes your order, serves and clears your tables.  She has 1 other helper and that's it!  It is a small place, but large enough to host a couple of large groups.  In fact there were 3 groups of 6+ people on while we were there, and the place got very loud very quickly.  To the point where we had to shout to talk. 

It's a great place to go with friends looking for some cheap eats.  There can be a little bit of a language barrier with the little lady, so best not stray from the menu too much when ordering.   We ordered some Bulgogi, Bibimbap  and tofu soups.  We did have one person on our table that asked for a Kimchi soup to not be spicy, and also we had someone with a sesame seed allergy so we asked for no sesame seeds.   Our meals came our with sesame seeds and the soups were at the normal spicy level.   There wasn't too much sesame seeds, so we were able to pick around it.   But we did send back one of the soups and instead of having a new one with less spice, it came back with extra spice.     After another 2-3 tries on explaining what we wanted, we were able to get a non-spicy soup. 

However the food was really great.  I would definitely come here again and the convenience of it opening up later is a huge bonus.
author: Maggie F.

description: I'm not sure what people consider good Korean food in San Francisco, but this soondubu jjigae was not good. It lacked a lot of flavor and was really watery. The price, while comparable to most other restaurants, was pretty high for the tiny bowl we got. They also charge $2 for extra rice which is pretty ridiculous. The banchan was pretty good, but I was really looking to find good tofu soup in San Francisco and sadly this disappointed.
author: Cat T.

description:
The boyfriend and I were craving some Korean food and tofu soup so we decided to try this place out. I've been here once before years ago, and I remember it being decent.

We ordered a tofu soup, a soy bean paste soup (doenjanjige), and a dolsot bibimbap. The tofu soup and doenjanjige were quite salty, and the dolsot bibimbap was nothing out of the ordinary -- just your regular dolsot bibimbap. 

The service is nice -- it's basically just the old Korean lady who runs the place. It's a bit grating to hear her constantly shout at the other lady worker during the meal...Could be a bit more professional about that.

Overall, an OK Korean restaurant.
author: Doris K.

description: One of my favorite Korean restaurant in SF. The restaurant is run by a lady who is wonderful. It feels very homey this place is more like a home style Korean restaurant if you're looking for a place that is somewhat authentic, definitely check the place out.
author: Tan D.

description:
I would never come back, and would never recommend this place to anyone. 

I ordered soy bean paste beef tofu soup and my girlfriend ordered yook gae jang. We also had sake, but everything went downhill from there. 

1. Side dishes did not come out unless requested and came out at the same time as the main dishes. 

2. My order did not contain beef, as it should. It was also so saturated with soy bean paste that there were chunks of undissolved soy bean paste. Worst part is that the undissolved soy bean paste looked like beef, which really got my hopes up. 

3. Upon asking for beef in my soup, I was given pork belly instead. 

4. My girlfriend who doesn't eat a lot was not full after her meal. 

5. Rice is free, but was not served unless asked. 

Giving one star because I have to, or else it would be zero.
author: Anthony L.

description:
How in the world did this place get such high reviews? I have no idea. Don't let its name fool you,this place not authentic at all, most of the workers in there speak fluent Chinese.

Came here with like 20 people on a Saturday night without reservations. We ordered the usual items but in larger portions: soondubu, jap chae, kimchi fried rice, galbi, haemul pajeon. The food must have food coloring because everything was bland and texture was off. Their bowls holding soondubu looked cracked and about to break on you. Soup was too watery and bland. It was definitely red in color, hardly any substance in the soup. Jap chae was just watery and noodles were overcooked and soggy. Kimchi fried rice was bland, it was literally kimchi and rice tossed in the same pan. Haemul pajeon was alright. Galbi was a bit overdone, but decent enough. 

Servers were rude, no smiles at all. We asked for refills on certain banchan (kimchi, bean sprouts) and the lady there pointed at the other banchan and said "you have them there" and then said "you still have some" for the one or two pieces of sprouts left. We were the only Asian customers, everyone else around were non-Asian. You can easily tell they had a better attitude towards them than us.

For that price, I'm sure I would like to spend it elsewhere. No wonder they could fit such a huge group on a late notice.
author: Connie C.

description:
One word: homey.

Was in search for a restaurant in this area still open at 10 and got here a couple hours before closing. This small restaurant has a family feel, run entirely by an elderly lady at the time we arrived.

Of course my go-to was a dol sot bi bim bap. Not disappointing at all! It came slightly sizzling and rice at the bottom of the pot was nicely crisp. Would recommend this for all bi bim bap lovers.

Also ordered a mandu appetizer. So. Good. Though the menu said potstickers, it's actually steamed dumplings. The sauce was a bit too salty for me though. Recommend this as a starter to share or small entree.

Service was excellent too.
The lady who was running this place does it all- taking orders, cooking, and refilling waters promptly. The best part was as we were about to leave, she was humming along to "All of Me" by John Legend as it started playing. Adorable!

Overall: comforting Korean food with a hospitable vibe. I'd come here again for sure.
author: Michelle L.

description: The waiter was very friendly, but the service was a bit slow. I had to ask for my rice, but the waiter apologized for forgetting to bring it to us in the first place. I was a little disappointed with my soondubu (tofu soup). There wasn't that much tofu or meat in my soup, which was disappointing. They also used a more firm type of tofu, so it isn't like the tofu soup that I am used to with the large amounts of extra soft tofu inside the soup. On the bright side, they give a generous amount of appetizers and refilled them quickly if you requested for more. I would only come here if it's convenient, but I must say that finding parking in this area on a Friday night can be really tough. So be prepared to drive around for awhile to find a spot during the dinner rush hour.
author: Lynn T.

description: Do not be fooled by the 4 and 5 star reviews. This place is disgusting. Duk bokki tasted as if it came from a packet. Do not come. Don't be fooled by comments of this "nice old lady." Rather have terrible service with edible food.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Not sure how this place got such high rating. The food is just ok, slightly below par. The price is really high for what it is.

Service is slow, and in more than one occasion I've observed blatant favoritism in terms of service. 

I gave it some benefits of doubts, but it never impressed me after multiple visits.

Maybe this place had its days. But alas it's no more.
author: Joseph L.

description:
I was craving bi bim bap but can't do the smokey bbq korean restaurants so I had resigned myself to doing takeout 
then I happen to find this place.

one loving korean woman who was our waitress and cook - made the most incredible Hae mul pa jun seafood pancake appetizer for my kid - it was SO HUGE
and then the STONE POT bi bim bap (CAN WE STAY HOT CRUNCHY RICE?) hit the spot on a super cold foggy SF day 

and the food was fresh and best of all NO SMOKE.

I am not super sensitive to gluten but I did err on the conservative side by not putting any sauce on my bi bim bap. (the soy sauce on the meat does have gluten- like most places- but I'm personally ok with some soy sauce). 

it was so much we had leftovers. hearty proportions!

CLEAN bathroom

it felt like a home cooked meal.

we will be back for sure!
author: Win H.

description: One amazing woman behind the register, in the kitchen and waiting tables. Food feels like I'm sitting in my best friend's mom's kitchen eating dinner (yes she's Korean). Usually no wait, food is a great price for what you get. One of my favorite places to get spicy soft tofu soup.
author: Sheri N.

description: I enjoyed the home cook style korean food here, probably the best traditional korean food place in SF.  So much respect to the owner here. She has no other employer but herself.
author: Mikey C.

description:
Came in late on a Friday night to a pretty empty restaurant. Initially glad we found a Korean restaurant with such good reviews open late  at night, but left pretty underwhelmed.
We kind of under-ordered (shared seafood pancake and ddukbokgi, and soft tofu for 4) and I think this kind of left a meh impression with the lady who seemed to be working by herself..

Side dishes pretty mediocre in terms of variety.
Ddukbokgi, which only had glass noodles and rice cakes, was pretty tasteless.
Also, we thought we ordered a medium seafood pancake but got charged for a large...  But we felt bad for under ordering (and intimidated) so we didn't say anything..

If I had to come back, I'd get the soft tofu!
author: Heyun J.

description:
Came in on a busy Saturday evening. All 7 tables were full. We stood in the storefront display (this awkward front window space that could fit another table perfectly but was oddly empty like it was some sacred burial site) like starved fat kids for about 15 minutes before the waitress even acknowledged us to tell us there would be a 45 minute wait. We waited. 

There was one 2 person table that opened up and a couple who came in immediately sat down at that table. They were brought water. They waited. And waited. And waited. They left (they didn't even order). They then crammed all 3 of us at this 2 person table (didn't even have an extra chair so we squeezed 2 on a bench).  We immediately placed our order. One of the bigger tables opened up and one waitress motioned that we would be able to switch over but a VERY RUDE lady came in talking loudly on her phone and approached and touched the waitress from behind while she was busing the table. She sat down at that table and loudly told her friends on the line that they had seating. (OUR TABLE.) 

Shortly after, OUR seafood pancake came out and was delivered to the table we were suppose to switch to. Obliviously, the rude lady started devouring it before her friends even arrived. For some reason unknown, she didn't even indicate or maybe even realize it was someone else's order. Her and her friends ordered in bouts of half chewed seafood pancake oozing from their mouths. We all stared in shock as our loving seafood pancake was ravenously consumed by 4 loud ladies who also stole our table. 

Next we waited. And waited. And waited. Our two beef tofu soups and hot stone bibimbap seemed to be served to other tables. Tables who sat down after us including the ladies who stole our table were served. I politely reminded the waitress we were STILL waiting and to please check up on our order since NOTHING has arrived yet. She was swamped and did not seem to check up on it. We waited. And waited. And waited. In the span of us waiting, we observed a pretty inconspicable yet convincing drug drop/pick up and 2 lonely strangers finding each other and becoming best friends. 

I hailed the waitress down again and she apologized profusely and offered us a beer to make up for it. We waited and chatted to the table next to us who saw the injustice of the table stealing, seafood devouring gluttons with no course of action to fix the wrongs. They were given their check BEFORE one of their orders even came. They told the waitress they never got one of their orders (another strike from the gluttonous pacman ladies?!). Upon learning it wasn't even in the works of being made, they just paid for what they ate and left. 

Finally our food came out. A thick, doughy seafood pancake, two very bland tofu soups with FIRM (not silken) tofu and a decent hot stone bibimbap but by no means is worth a trip over to this place.
author: Michelle W.

description:
Came here on New Year's Day after waiting way too long at Han Il Kwan. The owner is so nice here! She was the only one working; serving, cooking, everything, and smiling the whole time. Props to you lady! We got the kalbi, bulgogi, and kimchee fried rice. Everything came out sizzling. Everything tasted amazing. The kalbi was my favorite and the kimchee fried rice wasn't too spicy. Would've been perfect if the egg was yolky. The bulgogi was cut thicker than we're used to but we ended up liking it better than how other Korean places make it. 

We'll be back! Def our new go-to Korean spot. 

Fuck you Han Il Kwan and your long waits and priority tour buses!!
author: Michelle B.

description:
Ended up here the other day after a failed attempt in food adventuring. You know...the whole driving in circles looking for parking, parking spot won't fit your car type of ordeal when in San Francisco and then the place closes on you even tough you arrive 30 minutes before closing. Enough about that though....

I got to Um Ma Son around 10:30 at night and it was empty. When my friend and I walked in, we were greeted by two nice middle aged ladies. I love supporting small family businesses like these because it's almost literal home cooking when you dine at establishments like these.  By now, we were starving so we INHALED our ban chan. After much debate, we ended up ordering the kimchi pancakes, bulgogi and the kimchi fried rice. Everything we ordered was just alright in my opinion. I've had better Korean food elsewhere. The kimchi pancakes were good but they got mushy as we got to the center. The bulgogi was flavorful but a little tough, and the kimchi fried rice was a little too greasy and mushy for my taste. Put a fried egg on top and I'm happy again.

Overall my experience here was alright. 3 stars for the food and 4 stars for the service. I will definitely be back to try some of their other dishes.
author: Rosalyn L.

description: I love this place! The woman who runs it is super nice and always refills the banchan. The kimchi pancake is delicious and huge, I definitely recommend. Also great for groups and reasonably priced. Good selection of beers and soju as well!
author: Gina H.

description:
Food was okay. Tofu soup was under-seasoned, not spicy, and the tofu wasn't soft. My friend got the dol sot bibimbap which he liked, and the seafood pancake was decent.
The service, however, is atrociously inefficient and the restaurant is clearly understaffed.
I came with 2 other friends for dinner on a Saturday, and we ended up waiting 45 minutes for our food. We kept having to ask our server to check on our order because other People got their food before us, even though they came after us and ordered the same things we did!

Turns out there was a mix up and they sent our food to another table, even though they were seated long after us and hadn't even ordered yet. I don't know why the other guests didn't speak up, but that's another gripe for a different site. Needless to say, I watched longingly as another person devoured our seafood pancake. We weren't the only ones with issues though -the table next to ours never got one dish.

The waitress was really apologetic, so that helped a little. They also took one item off our bill. 
I feel bad for the poor waitress working that night. She was the only English-speaking staff member, and she was really sweet but it looked like she was struggling with the hellish nightmare level of Diner Dash IRL.

Wouldn't come back unless I was literally the only one in the restaurant.
author: Kat H.

description:
We went here in a Sunday night , and it wasn't that busy so we thought we would give it a shot. There was only one lady working both the kitchen and the floor , but that didn't make any difference in the speed of things coming out . She was amazing , the food came out quick and tasted great . 
Not only that, but she was so sweet and welcoming , she held my 9 month old son so my friend and I could eat without having to shoveling the food in our mouths.  This place was small , welcoming, and warming . 
We got the kimchi pancake  , tofu soup , and the jap che noodles.  Everything was great . My only issue was they didn't have any ramen noodles for the soup .  
Another great thing about this place is it doesn't break your wallet . All of that was only 30 dollars . I will defiantly be coming back here .
author: Isabella E.

description: We called ahead to ask about their very special soup.  The lady said not today.  We went any way to ask in person.  No special soup and was told on Thursday.  Apparently this beef soup is very good.  We ate their any way.  Seafood pancake, very thick, served very fast.  Vegetable soup, ok. Thinly sliced pork belly with sauce made from oil and pepper.  I liked the onion.  The mancha was refilled.  I liked the potato and lots of sprouts. Bean curd.  Really liked the kimchi, very sweet and not spicy at all.  The place was empty and we had the whole restaurant to ourselves for about an hour.  The lafy who took our orde, cooked, served, gave us our bill ran the place by herself.  Amazing!
author: Helen L.

description: The food here is fresh and delicious! The proprietor of the establishment is a sweetheart who made us feel like we were eating at her dinner table. Highly recommend!!
author: Alexander G.

description:
We came here on a Thursday night after Turtle Tower was closed at 7pm! We ordered the seafood pancake, tofu and beef kimchi soup, and the bbq beef. All of the food was delicious! What was even more impressive was the fact that the sweet owner lady ran the whole restaurant and kitchen herself!

She was very attentive to us. I never knew this place existed since it's away from the other restaurants on Geary Blvd. Would definitely be back!
author: V M.

description:
When I got home from my trip to Seoul, I was immediately saddened by my current Korean spots. Then I walked into this place on a whim and it all changed!!! 

I was not let down by this place at all. In fact, it tasted just like the small family owned places I fell in love with in Seoul.

The food seemed authentic and had tons of flavor. Meats are fattier than your typical SF restaurant but that's what it's like when I ate this food abroad too. That's flavor baby! The spicy rice cake and seafood pancake rocked my world too!

Most impressive was the fact that it was being run solo, yes solo, by the sweetest little old lady who barely speaks English. I walked in behind a family of 5 (we were the whole place at that point) and she got all their food out quickly and mine was only minutes  behind. What a lady!!!

Anyway, def give this place a try. It's a true gem!
author: Margaret O.

description:
Overall, I'd say this place is alright. Not amazing, but not terrible. I'd probably come here as a backup if other locations were closed. The food is great, but definitely on the salty side. 

korean pancake - large seemed like what is traditionally a reg size
bulgogi - reg size plate, would say it's standard
other red meat - reg size plate, again it's standard
spicy rice cake - very salty, and seemed extra doughy, which can be good or bad depending on your preference for how rice cakes are cooked
seafood hot tofu soup - salty, a bit lacking in the seafood
reg hot tofu soup - salty, was more standard
author: Gabriel C.

description:
The lady who served us was the friendliest sweetest lady every! Love love love her.

We ordered seafood pancake and Kalbi. Both were delicious, especially loved that the pancake was not too oily. Perfect balance of crispy and doughy texture.
author: Sarah H.

description: The woman did everything by herself. That part was pretty impressive! Came here late after a day of sightseeing in the city. The lady was quick with the service and food. She even brought out refills on the banchans while we waited. The food was delicious!
author: Jessica D.

description:
My facebook status relationship with Umma: "it's complicated". I always did wonder how she kept up the 2am business hours given her apparent level of customership.

I'm not mad at the new Tuesday - Sunday 5:30 pm - 12 [am] posted hours. What gets me is her coloring outside the lines. Several times I've shown up at 11:30 pm to a closed establishment. On a different week, I was there just after 9:30 pm. Aaaaaaand it was closed again, this time with a random "we are closed today, sorry for the inconvenience" sign. She apologized when I mentioned the anomalies in person, but apologies don't make my stomach any less hungry.

I realize she should probably be enjoying retirement out on a golf course somewhere and that she's not obligated to hustle at this stage in her life. But how about this: please either honor your own posted business hours or post ones that reflect when people can actually go in and get food. You're killing me, granny, and not even softly.
author: Dan B.

description:
After a late afternoon run around Lake Merced, bf and I were too lazy to go grocery shopping and cook dinner at home.  Bf was set on having Korean food.  First, we went to Toyose but it was already crowded and a 45 min wait didn't sound too appealing to us.  Determined to have his Korean din, bf and I headed to Um Ma Son after doing a quick search on yelp. 

When we arrived at UMS, the place was pretty empty around 8pm.  Only two tables occupied the small eatery.  We were a little weary but nonetheless happy about not having to wait.  There were three ladies running the place - owner, chef and waitress.  The waitress was welcoming.

We ordered a small Seafood Pancake, Kimchi Pork, Tofu and Vermicelli Stir-fry and rice.  The banchan came out promptly after we ordered.  Pretty standard but my fav was the pickled cucumbers, which were a refreshing contrast to the spicy kimchi.  I even asked for more cucumbers and the owner gladly gave us generous seconds.  The seafood pancake was a bit too greasy and could use more seafood.  For a small size, it was actually pretty big and we took some home.  The stir-fry was lacking meat which was a bit of a bummer.  There was plenty of tofu and kimchi but we only found roughly 6 tiny slices of meat in the entire dish.

The prices were reasonable and food was decent.  It definitely has a mom and pop shop.   However, I'm not sure if I'd go back considering that there are many Korean and KBBQ restaurants in the Sunset and Richmond.  Um Ma Son is worth a try at least once though.
author: Liv A.

description:
Alright so the food was good. The kimchi wasn't. 

Honestly the customer service was really horrible because my friend and I went there around 10p.m., it closes at 12, and the lady seemed really tired. She didn't let us share one dish and demanded us to buy two. I asked about another dish, then she reluctantly gave in. Her temper just made everything awkward. And I think because we shared the food, she made us pay more than necessary. I ordered the soy bean soup which was I believe $10 and the bill came up to be $16.75 which I didn't understand. But I just didn't want to argue so I paid it... 

The experience here was really shit. I would not recommend anyone to come here unless you have a big group of friends and will buy lots of food..
author: Tricia T.

description:
Great Korean food. Love this place. I come here often with my family and they are always friendly and attentive. 

The food is solid.
author: Mark J.

description:
We called to ask if we could come in for 2 people for dinner and asked for a reservation. They said "no problem, just come in, come in" and hung up without asking for our names -- we drove straight over, found parking, and walked in. The place was half empty, but when we got there they said there were no tables because a party of 15 was coming.

There seemed to be space, and I told them we'd called ahead. They just told us again that there weren't any tables. Hungry and pissed.
author: Scott H.

description:
I've been meaning to try this place based on the great reviews, and I've finally tried it. I decided on the dol sot bibimbap, and while it was good, there was hardly any meat in it! The banchan were ok. None of them were spicy at all, though. 

The service was ok.
author: Rachel H.

description:
WHY is Korean food SO expensive in SF? Yeup, here I go AGAIN...

Some say it's the "complimentary" banchan. But that's like asking a waiter at a steakhouse, "Why does the filet mignon cost $50?" and him responding, "Because you get a 'complimentary' baked potato...". WTF.  Others say it's because there's a lack of Korean restaurants in SF. That makes no damn sense when there's one on nearly every block or two in The Richmond. If anything, Korean Restaurants in the area should be cheap(er) to remain competitive.   

I've never paid anything less than $40 for Korean food which is why I almost always eat it only after 2 AM. At that point, what's another $40-$50 after making it rain at the bar? No wonder my credit card statements are giving me the one finger salute every month. *Le sigh*

Enter Um Ma Son, a Mom & Pop Korean restaurant that you can leave fully satisfied and buzzed for "cheap" (most dishes are $3 - $8 less than other Korean restaurants). The food was just as good as the homely service. The owner is a sweetheart  and is a one woman show, she take orders, cooks, and waits on your table. Bless her heart. 

Mr. NSS, Jizz Master J, Lap Dance Linda, and I ordered the following including 2 bottles of Chamisul (Korean Soju), and had leftovers for $35/person including tax and tip. 

*COMPLIMENTARY BANCHAN
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/NcwP3kUy90oadOkRLcGO4w?select=8wg5bIjDpkPt-rQ_YqSiIQ#8wg5bIjDpkPt-rQ_YqSiIQ
From the kimchi, pickled daikon, anchovies, fish cakes to cucumber, the 8 types of banchan were fresh and a perfect accompaniment to our meal.  

*GOKI SOON DU BU (Kimchi Soft Tofu Soup - $8.95) - 4 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/NcwP3kUy90oadOkRLcGO4w?select=8wg5bIjDpkPt-rQ_YqSiIQ#L33xHohIeq7-kEzD38vjew
Nothing says comfort like a bubbling bowl of soon du bu (served tableside by the owner) with a spicy yet soothing broth and silken tofu. 

*HAEMUL PAJUN (Seafood Pancake - $10.95) - 4 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/NcwP3kUy90oadOkRLcGO4w?select=oCYfdnPzw-SM2duamvNHxw#m2rHqEYcqPwp7Wkrse58dA
The seafood pancake had a nice crispy exterior throughout and was not limp and soggy like others I've had. It was generously filled with shrimp, octopus and squid so you got a bite of the ocean sea with each bite. 

*KALBI (Beef Short Ribs - $19.95) - 4 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/NcwP3kUy90oadOkRLcGO4w?select=oCYfdnPzw-SM2duamvNHxw#Ixqzlo4-Nlt5XUb-Nni3_Q
Sizzling on the platter, the tender kalbi had a mouth-watering savory sweetness with a subtle smokiness from the grill. 

*SAM GYUP SAL (Pork Belly - $15.95) - 2 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/NcwP3kUy90oadOkRLcGO4w?select=oCYfdnPzw-SM2duamvNHxw#IVTlZ6kUglc_8Cnhxs-51A
The least favorite of all the dishes, the pork belly was underseasoned and overcooked. It was still edible but unexpected given pork belly is such a fatty cut of meat. 

*KIMCHI DUK BOK UM (Stir Fried Korean Rice Cakes w/ Kimchi - $12.95) - 4 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/NcwP3kUy90oadOkRLcGO4w?select=oCYfdnPzw-SM2duamvNHxw#oCYfdnPzw-SM2duamvNHxw
I'm normally not a fan of Korean rice cakes because I find that a lot of places do not properly cook it causing the rice cakes to have a gummy texture. However, Um Ma Son's was on-point. It had a soft tender chew that was satisfying especially with the fiery kick from the kimchi. 

SOLID KOREAN FOOD: CHECK!
RECESSION-FRIENDLY PRICES: CHECK!
FRIENDLY SERVICE: CHECK!
CLOSES LATE (2 AM): YAY FOR DRUNKTARDS!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Okay, first off, I am SO CONFUSED as to how this place has 4 stars?!? ....and let me tell you why.

We ordered three dishes: ddokbokki, seafood pancake, and an order of the seafood tofu soup. The ddokbokki had absolutely ZERO flavor, not to mention it had no vegetables or other standard ingredients that's normal to the dish (it was only ddeok/ rice cake and glass noodles...what?!?) The pancake was also bland, doughy, and lacked the crispness that a Korean pancake should have. The seafood tofu soup was the best of the three (but that doesn't mean it was good; it was mediocre at best) 

Now, let's get in to the service. There was only one woman working there (Umma Son, perhaps?), and she was doing both the waiting and the cooking. There was only one other party of two besides our table. When our party of four only ordered three dishes, she seemed annoyed by the fact and definitely let it show on her face. When we get the bill, we find that she overcharged us for one dish. We grab the menu to recheck the prices, and a few seconds later, she grudgingly takes the menu back from our table and slams it back on her cashier, like we broke some kind of law by touching her menu. Literally, every little action she did just made you feel like you did something wrong. We ended up not correcting her about the overcharged dish in the end because we didn't want to add any more fuel to her fire. According to some past reviews, however, overcharging/ charging arbitrary numbers is not rare here so GUYS JUST DOUBLE CHECK YOUR BILLS! Needless to say, this was one of, if not, the most unpleasant and uncomfortable dining experiences I've had.

I'm all about supporting small mom and pop shops, but when neither their food nor service is good, I have no reason to ever come back.
author: Tiffany S.

description:
Chanced upon Um Ma Son while looking for dinner.

We settled on Jeuk Suk Gam Ja Tang  (spicy potato soup with pork and various vegetables cooked on table top) and it was one of the best tasting Korean casserole dishes I've tasted. The soup had a nice smoky hammy flavor and perfectly balanced in terms of spice/salt level and the potatoes melted in the mouth beautifully once fully cooked. The pork (neck) was tender and fall off the bone delicious. 

A one-woman show, the owner was both waitress and chef - a unique experience :) as long as she is not too busy.

Banchan was average with some notables (warm potatoes, fish cakes, pickled jalapenos) and a couple of failures (eg. the two types of bean sprouts).
author: M Y.

description:
Incredible spicy tofu soup and kalbi that is not too salted or overly sweet.

The owner is always moving a mile a minute, but takes the time to smile and say hello to everyone.

Our go to spot for Korean in the city.
author: Christian M.

description:
This is more like 2.5 stars (but I like the old lady, so I'll bump it up). Let me preface this by saying that the food here is really good. We got - seafood pancake, kalbi and Kim chi fried rice. All these dishes were delicious. So why 2.5 stars then? Read on (if you like my ranting). 

My friends and I came around 9:30pm on a Friday night. We quickly got seated and were given our menus. The lady who seated us, seemed extremely busy, running back and forth serving from table to table (god bless her). 

Meanwhile, my girlfriend and I noticed this extremely loud woman at the table across from us. Think Margaret Cho, but louder, more annoying and even more drunk. She was laughing and talking at the top of her lungs and we overhear her say that her mom owns the restaurant. At this point the lines are blurred on whether she actually knew the people she was drinking with or if these were just customers. But hey, she was hooking them up with the free soju. 

Somehow she (miraculously) makes her way to our table and asks us how we're doing and if we ordered. She could barely fit in between the small space between our table and the next, and it made me uncomfortable how close her stomach was to my plate.. Anyway, she slurred the words "I'll be back with your side dishes" and stumbled to the next table. 

Needless to say, she didn't come back with the side dishes. The poor woman who was helping us before brought it out, along with our waters and tea. Wtf was the point of Margaret Cho coming to our table??? 

As more people come through the door and get seated, this lady is making a fool of herself trying to "help" out, causing all of us at the restaurant to have looks of confusion on our faces. She even tried to move a table of 6 to a smaller table...what? 

This is all going down while her mother and the other waitress are busting their asses trying to RUN a business. Finally, she finds a table in the corner and I'm guessing these are her actual friends and drinks with them the rest of the night. I peeked at her during my meal and she was stuffing her face with her hands (no utensils needed).

So here's to Margaret Cho - how about you take your alcoholism elsewhere, or at least stop playing server when inebriated. 

The other waitress deserves a raise for the kind of shenanigans she had to put up with.
author: Andy H.

description:
Small little restaurant, but great food! It's not all hyped up like most Korean restaurants around SF, but definitely the same quality. Been here twice, both an hour or two before closing time. It was really quiet and we were the only table. 

The restaurant is run by a older Korean lady and she does it all! Or at least during the time I was here. She was the only person working and she even locked the doors for her own safety inside. We had to knock for her to unlock the doors for us. 

The food came quick! I'm still confused by how she can cook so many dishes in such a small amount of time. 

Only downside is that both occasions we were here, we wanted to get the fried fish but she was out :/ 

Will definitely be back to support her business. Very sweet lady!
author: Weylie H.

description:
This is a decent place for Korean food. My friend and I ordered the dokbuki with ramen appetizer, a seafood soondubu and a kalbi. The entrees were both delicious (love me some juicy kalbi) but the dokbuki appetizer was pretty dry and sauceless. 

I give this place a 3 mainly because they seem a bit disorganized. Owner is Korean and does all the cooking and she has two Chinese ladies helping her out. The waitresses are nice but seem pretty new. At the end when we wanted our check, all three of them were in the kitchen. Anyone could have easily left without paying. I hope they'll tighten up the service side a bit because the food is decent! 

Note: they're open until midnight!
author: Joanna H.

description: This place is amazing. Insanely quick service by the same charming lady, quality home made food, and zero wait times. It has become a regular on the rotation--I crave it weekly!
author: Leah H.

description:
Alright, so.  According to the review guidelines, we're not suppose to talk about "employment practices, political ideologies...other matters that don't address the core of the consumer experience" but...I think this needs to be said.

The woman who runs this restaurant is EMOTIONALLY, MENTALLY, AND PHYSICALLY ABUSIVE.  A good friend of mine worked here as a server for several months and while she was there: 
- was paid under the table (yeah, sure)
- was never allowed to keep her tips (...kay)
- was consistently berated/cussed at (uhhh)
- was called out for being slow or stupid yet preferred over a "Chinese employee" because, according to this woman, the Chinese are "slow minded" (whhaaaaaattt the fu-)
- was purposely shoved during one of these usual rants about how terrible of an employee my friend is (she's not)

Please, please, please read past reviews.  Those who have mentioned that they've heard the owner yelling at servers in the kitchen, cussing under her breath at customers, charging some arbitrary number (because she WILL ADD TO YOUR TOTAL if she feels you didn't order enough)...you're not crazy!  It's true. This woman is the worst.

And.  She may seem really sweet but according to my friend, she has and WILL compliment you/butter you up, and then say the utmost terrible stuff behind your back in Korean, assuming you won't understand.  She's called people ugly, sluts, bitches, etc.  And not in a way that is typical within the service/food industry.  I'm a waitress, I get frustrated.  I get it.  But no.  This woman will go out of her way to compliment you and then maliciously comment on how you look, act, eat, breathe, simply exist, whatever.  It gets racist, too.  

My friend wants to move on and put her time at Um Ma Son behind her but I'm gonna continue to be angry for her.  I've read reviews that mention the terrible ways a business will treat its employees and customers and, lol, have eaten there anyway.  Because, like, what's the point, really.  My one shitty review isn't gonna stop this woman from being a shitty person.  So, please.  As you were.  Just know this woman sucks.

Other than that...food is pretty good.
author: Ano N.

description:
Very #delish Korean place!!  Taste just like Ajumma made it at home. Nom-ed my heart out. 

No wait during a weeknight and the food came out very quickly after ordering. Their side dishes are fresh and the BBQ meat dishes really bring my inner BEAST and BIG BANG out. 


Also tried the mandu soup which would make even the SNSD girls eat more than they're probably allowed to LOLL. 

Oh yeah and the fried pan cake thingy was très yum yum. 

=^..^=
author: Stephen H.

description: This place has become our go to spot to get our quick Korean fix. Its within walking distance from our house, plus its open late. The one woman show of the place is awesome. She is very kind and the service is always friendly. Reminds me of my own grandma. Our favorite dishes are the kimchi chige and the bulgogi. The banchan selection is also very good.
author: Derek D.

description: The food is really good and the ladies are very friendly!! This place is a must visit!
author: Khim Y.

description:
Pretty typical food And environment. Wasn't very exceptional. The lady was nice though. I think be cause she thought I was Korean. She sure knows how to up sell. I let her though as she seems to work really hard by herself. They can use a little more decoration and brighter lights. 

I have a feeling the reason why this place is highly rated is a lot of people see the lady working on her own so late. Just saying
author: Geezy L.

description:
Rating: 3.5 

Happy (late) Easter Sunday! 

The original plan for the night was to eat hot pot. Hot pot and K-BBQ are two completely different things. We originally went to Shabu House on Ocean but it was closed (I guess due to Easter Sunday). My bf really wanted hot pot, so we found one in Richmond (Grassland Hot Pot). Got there and it was closed too...we assumed it was because of Easter Sunday again but then we saw a sign that it was suspended because of something with alcohol. You can guess our facial expressions: -____-
Haha. So we searched on Yelp for anything close by to eat, since most places seemed to be closed around 10 pm. Um Ma Son was open! So we headed there...

Entering Um Ma Son, only one man sat at the table. My party of 3 was seated at the table in the back by the register. Eventually about 2 more parties came in later that night. 

The place is kinda small but a good size. The ladies working here that night were sweet, but understaffed. They only had one person waiting the tables/register, and one working in the kitchen. Parking was a bit easier than usual because it was late-night and Easter Sunday. The price is a few bucks cheaper than other Korean restaurants in the city. 

I think the overall food quality was mediocre. My friend and I ordered the seafood pancake, spicy pork, and kalbi to share. On a side note, our banchans arrived after 2 plates was already served.. 

Seafood pancake: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/um-ma-son-san-francisco?select=L33xHohIeq7-kEzD38vjew#biSUwtWcCrQ0T4D4cCMruQ
Ordered seafood pancake cause it was in the highlights, but then again, what Korean restaurant isn't popular for their seafood pancake?! Haha. I like this one cause it was meatier than other restaurants. (More shrimps! I think..) They also come with a sauce but I forgot to try it :(

Kalbi: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/um-ma-son-san-francisco?select=L33xHohIeq7-kEzD38vjew#sRRS4MsO7Uta0PwAufxlKg
When Kalbi and spicy pork first came out, it was  sizzling! It was like zzzzz... *makes the sizzle noise* :) 
The Kalbi was alright. The flavor didn't stand out too much but it was a good amount to bring out the taste still. 

Spicy Pork: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/um-ma-son-san-francisco?select=L33xHohIeq7-kEzD38vjew#XLoTN4UInuEVzzdXzvw-LA
This plate was a bit of a disappoint. It was good, but it wasn't spicy...and I like my food spicy. I think the spice to it was more mild than spicy. Probably a 6/10 in 'hotness' ranking, haha. (See what I did there? Haha!) 

Rice: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/um-ma-son-san-francisco?select=L33xHohIeq7-kEzD38vjew#eFsSXBE_HE5XA5z6EAXu3A
Yeah...who writes a review on rice? Lol. I just wanted to comment that they serve a little less than what other restaurants do. 

Overall, I think this is a decent restaurant to go to if you have some late night craving for Kbbq. Open till midnight!
author: Mandy G.

description:
We came here because we wanted Korean food but the place we originally wanted to go was too busy. The restaurant is fairly clean, not too big (7 tables of 4) and has a bathroom. They serve traditional side dishes like bean sprouts, kimchi, tofu, and marinated potatoes. We were served 5 minutes after we ordered our dishes. 

For my main dish, I got noodles with kimchi, tofu, bean sprouts and beef. It was a big dish for $13. If you don't like spicy food, don't order this because it is pretty spicy. The dish was okay but only had very few pieces of beef. You can definitely eat the dish for two meals with rice, even though there is noodle inside. 

Overall, nothing too special about the restaurant. If you are craving for Korean food it is definitely not a bad choice. But if you are looking for LA-level Korean BBQ dishes, then you probably want to do a little more research.
author: Wendy F.

description:
Can't believe I haven't been to Um Ma Son until last night. What the heck!?
It is a tiny mother/daughter spot and open SUPER late! THANK YOU! 

My friends got there before me. I told them to just order and I'd order for myself when I got there. I had a hankering for some kalbi tang but I didn't wind up getting any because everything my friends ordered were HUGE!

The dishes are traditional Korean style.. 
Japchae was on the oilier side but it is mighty tasty.
The samgyeopsal  (Korean bacon) came with a sauce that consisted of sesame oil, salt & pepper. I thought that you eat samgyeopsal w/ lettuce, rice, and red pepper paste but my friend told me the sesame oil sauce is the old school ajumma way. 
I'm down with that.
Seafood pancake is HUGE and they don't skimp you on the seafood in it. I ate with 2 other people and we didn't even kill half of it. 
Bibimbap comes out perfect. The owner squirts the paste on and mixes it all up for you. She lovingly gave us each some of the crispy rice before continuing to mix the rice. Ugghhh the best paaarrrtttttttttttt
Spicy pork bulgogi .. You know, I normally don't eat pork unless it's bacon but the spicy pork bulgogi was done soooo well. Marinated to perfection.

I need to come back for some kalbi tang and ddukbokki though. Those are my 2 loves.
author: Susy C.

description:
We came on a Thursday night, and it was totally empty. It actually looked closed but it wasn't. I was a little worried since we were literally the only people in there, but we went for it. Kimchee pancake, bul go gi, and jap chae, plus all the ban chan you would expect! The owner,  an older lady, was so sweet! She gave us a bottle of beer to split on the house.

The food was pretty darn good! The kimchee pancake wasn't spicy at all, but really flavorful. The same is true of the bul go gi! The jap chae wasn't my favorite, and next me we go, because there will be a next time, I'd like to order a rice dish like one of the bibimbap or the kimchee fried rice! We'll definitely be back!
author: Hannah A.

description: 20 mins after we ordered the owner came by saying the waitress forgot that our table was reserved and asked us to move to another table. We were actually ok with that but the waitress already started to move all of our utensils and food to the other table where a couple of guests just left and the table was still full of food residuals. We asked the waitress to clean the other table before move our food there. The waitress just grabbed my used napkin and roughly wiped it. I asked her again if she could wipe the wet area and she reluctantly did with a random towel she grabbed from another table. The food is not good either - only one piece of seafood (a clam) in the 9.95 seafood tofu soup without rice (they gave the rice to us after we asked).
author: Zhelu Z.

description: Great service. GREAT FOOD. Cooked and served by a kind granma. Definitely recommend this place.
author: Mallem T.

description:
Food is better here than many near by korean restaurant. 

1. KAL BI 
2. Seafood pancake -actually..a bit oily
3. Kimchi chigae is really yum

I give this place 4 stars because people that hate on this place really need to cut the owner lady some slack. The woman is running the whole place by herself probably to save on overhead. She is busting her fanny here to serve you! And to keep this place running!

Business is tough and competitive, i give her 5 stars for effort!!

FIGHTING! Umma son.
author: Moto B.

description:
It was around 9pm on a Sunday and my bf and I had limited options on where to go eat because a lot of places close early on Sunday. So, anyway, I searched for Korean food and this restaurant came up nearby.

We circled the block once and found parking right in front and the place was actually empty when we walked in. We were seated by the window and the lady gave us our menus. 

The bf had a beef dish over rice and egg and I ended up getting the kimchee fried rice with chicken instead of beef. We had tea and water to drink. Our food came
out in 15 mins. 

The bf's food was still sizzling when it was brought out and we both immediately noticed how skimpy his meal was. There were literally only 3 slivers of beef and more rice than anything else. He was very disappointed. My kimchee fried rice was a good size, but the rice was too mushy and there was barely any chicken. It did however, have a good spicy kick to it. But, that was about the only thing I liked about it.

Overall, for what we ordered, we were not satisfied whatsoever. Having spent $25 on food we didn't enjoy was terrible. The best thing about our dinner that night was probably the service because the mother and daughter were both very nice. But, unfortunately, we won't be coming back.
author: Fallon P.

description: This is a China managed restaurant. Service is like way of Chinese. Food is not like traditional. Not recommend.
author: Phong N.

description:
You know a good Korean food by the side dishes.  As soon as the side dishes were placed on the table after having waited for 10 minutes...it was a shit show.  Flavored were one dimensional:  salty.

Worst Korean food I've ever eaten.  Kimchi fried rice with beef was super greasy and barely had any need on it.  Took a few bites and didn't even eat the rest, disgusting.  Also order the spicy beef noodle soup and broth lacked complexity, tasted like ramen noodle.
author: Mike S.

description: The owner of this restaurant is one of the sweetest of women you will ever meet. She made sure we were satisfied overall and even brought us more appetizer dishes when she overheard us talking about our absolute favorite ones. The gal bi was very delicious and made by her. She was also the craziest multi-tasker ever! I watched her serve 7-8 parties, took orders, prepared and served appetizers, cooked all the main courses, answered the phones, and brought everyone their checks. The wait for everything was not bad at all either and I swear she did it all so gracefully. I would definitely go back and I have to say this is my new favorite Korean BBQ restaurant.
author: Veronica L.

description: The owner was very kind and really attentive. Name of the place suites the food - tasted like I was eating a home cooked meal from my mom!
author: Angela K.

description:
A-OK is definitely how I would put it.

Decent Korean food if you are fiending - not necessarily somewhere I'd go out of my way to go to though.

Our top 2 choices had waits 30minutes+, so we decided to resort to trusty Yelp and look for other Korean alternatives.  This place had 0 minute wait and was mostly full (promising).

3 of us ordered:
Kimchi seafood pancake
Soondubu (large size for 2)
Spicy Pork bbq
Dok Bok Ki (rice cake)

We began with panchan which was standard (bonus points for fish cakes and potatoes).  I would say the highlight was the soondubu. Everything was pretty decent, although not remarkably memorable.
author: Adele Z.

description: For a very "mom and pop" shop I would expect more, but the flavors and quality of cooking are fairly average compared to other K-restaurants in the City.
author: Art W.

description:
Their kimchi fried rice was average. It wasn't delicious but it wasn't awful either. The rice was a tad bland and wasn't as spicy as I had hoped. 

However, their tofu soup was delicious. It was very well flavored and the tofu was more firm than most places. They actually cook the tofu in chunks, instead of the usually small pieces that break as soon as you try to mix the soup.

The service was decent. They were understaffed that night and only had one person working. Regardless, she got our food to us in the timely manner.

Not a bad meal for the price and they're open late!
author: Ray W.

description:
Worst. Korean. Restaurant. Ever.

Trust a foodie and not the hungry late night crowd that gives this place 4 stars.

Food:
-Extremely stingy on ingredients despite typical Korean restaurant prices

-Seafood Tofu Soup (1 clam, 1 shrimp) was super salty and had a weird sour flavor

-Beef soup was better but had only 2 pieces of beef and cost $13

Service:
In keeping with the cheapness theme, the owner hired two rude/incompetent waitresses whose only fluent language is Cantonese. 

Have a question about the menu? "I don't know. What number you order? WHAT NUMBER?" 

Table is dirty? Allow me to zing my dirty rag all over the table, flopping onto your side dishes in the process.

Finally comfortable at the table? Oops, we forgot it's needed for a big table reservation. Time to move, chop chop.

Why would anyone want to make a reservation at a place like this? It seems like people come here just to hang out late at night, and don't really care about the food or service.
author: Keith L.

description:
The meal came with a bunch of side dishes like spicy fish cakes, potatoes, bean sprout.
The seafood pa jun was really delicious!  There was enough amount of vegetables, octopus, and shrimp.  

We also got the spicy bulgogi. It's wasn't that spicy, but I kinda wanted a little more heat. 

Our third dish was spicy rice cake, which did meet my expectation. We underestimated the amount and then realized the proportion was more than enough.
author: Michelle N.

description:
tl;dr

Best tofu chigae in the city. Open till 2 AM most days!!

---

Um Ma Son is one of those places that you don't want too many people to know about, because once too many people catch on to the secret, then the place will go downhill. It's like discovering a local cafe that has ample seating and plenty of outlets, but is somehow strangely quiet on a Saturday afternoon - you definitely want to keep that on the DL!! ;)

We've been here no less than six or seven times, with our first visit here to try the Kalbi-Chim (stewed kalbi in sweet sauce with potatoes and carrots) on a recommendation from a friend. He said that Um Ma Son had the best rendition of it that he has ever tasted in the US, and highly recommended us to go - I made it a mental note to try Um Ma Son the next time when I was in SF.

Honestly, I don't remember that much about the Kalbi-Chim that day over a year ago, but our Korean dining scene in SF has never been the same since.

Like other Yelpers mentioned, UMS is literally a one (wo)man show, with a nice Korean lady that handles all the cooking, serving, and cleaning after hours (around 10:30 or so). We've learned that apparently when you go earlier she has a helper or two, but they actually get off work at around 10 or so since we've seen them leave. 

The menu is generally Korean home-style dishes. They have some KBBQ too, but with Han Il Kwan so close and the prices for meat quite expensive at UMS, we have never gotten it.

We've had a great sampling of their other dishes, and out of what we've had, we highly recommend the TOFU CHIGAE.

UMS honestly makes the best tofu chigae in the city (yes, I've been to My Tofu House - which is a close runner-up). The soup for some reason is extremely savory, but very rarely salty or too spicy (which appears to often be cop-out methods at restaurants to make their tofu chigaes more palatable). The savoriness of the broth has made UMS a go-to place for us on cold evenings when a warm bowl of broth seems extremely appealing. :)

Other than that, I really enjoy their KIMCHI BO KUM (stir-fried tofu, pork, kimchi, and jap chae noodles). It goes really well with rice and I think they make one of the best renditions of this dish. 

We've had their bibimbap, seafood pancake, and the kalbitang, and although they all received passing marks, none were solidly in the "outstanding" category. The kalbi-chim was actually pretty decent, but after we had the corresponding dish (and kalbitang) at Han Il Kwan, we suspect that HIK probably just generally makes better kalbi dishes than UMS.

Her banchan is usually so-so, with a few tasty ones (I like the spicy radish when she has it and the fish cake), they come in really small dishes but she will be very happy to refill it for you :) She actually packs banchan in to-go orders, which I thought was really thoughtful :) (although apparently standard now among many Korean places?!) 

FREE RICE REFILLS. About ~$12-17 per person, depending on what you get.

Bottom line - do your tummy a favor and come here and get a bowl of chigae. It's an amazing place to come on a cold night around midnight when you just crave something hot to eat. During your meal, look out at the deserted Geary Blvd., and have a pensive conservation with your dining partner. (in all our history of eating here, we've never seen the place more than 3 tables full - and this is including meals before 9! - often it's just you, her, and the empty dining room)

But really, take a moment to appreciate this dedicated Korean lady's cooking. It's fairly excellent, and I can't imagine how she keeps a restaurant running day after day till the wee hours of 2 AM. Looking at her cautiously lock the front door between customers after 11 PM, I wonder how and why she keeps this restaurant going. But lets not speculate - perhaps all you need to know is simply contained in those piping stone pots - all those solitary nights condensed into countless bowls of warm tofu chigae.
author: Chris S.

description:
We came in right before closing on a Thursday night. The place was pretty much entirely run by one woman, so majorly impressed. She was literally cooking, cleaning, and waiting on all the tables at once.. it was about 11pm and all the tables were full, probably because most people had off the next day. 
The food was pretty good. I got the soon dubu, which was just okay.. the tofu wasn't the best I've ever had, but the flavor was pretty good. A little skimpy on the beef - I only got 4 or 5 tiny pieces. 
High rating for the woman running it because you don't see that very often!
author: Fifi Y.

description: The lady here is so sweet. Food was homey and delicious! No one was around but I highly suspect it is because Yelp has been marked as temporarily closed for some reason. :(
author: Denise D.

description: The food was not tasty, and it was far from being authentic. My food was not clean - I'm still sitting in the restroom.
author: Chelsea C.

description: A one woman show. "Grandma"  cooks,hosts and everything else.Her take on Korean food pays homage to classic comfort food that is so well executed.Come here if the wait at Korean brothers  restaurant become unbearable.MUST TRY ITEMS: kimchee pancake,Duk Mhan Du Guk( just like Kal bi tang but better!)
author: aj s.

description:
Um Ma God, Um ma Son to the rescue!  We were craving some serious Korean food.  We actually went for another Korean restaurant around the corner but that place looked like it had a line for K-Pop boy-band concert, too hungry to wait in line so Um Ma Goodness fit the bill.

The Yuk Kae Jang was very tasty, hot and spicy with just enough kick wake a sleepy palate.  The rice/cake noodles and Ban'Chan also did not disappoint.  Though I must say, it's not the best massive Ban'Chan I've ever had - some Korean restaurants drown you with so much Ban'Chan and that ain't a bad thing!
author: Adonis V.

description: Best Korean food in SF. The woman who works here knows how to cook and is so attentive. Accommodating to vegan/ vegetarian needs. The service is great and good is how cooked. Would highly recommend
author: Campbell R.

description: Great home cooked Korean place.  A bit at the end of Geary but if you decide to make the trek this spot is worth it (it is right next to Aziza and if you cant find parking you can pay to valet at Aziza).  Great place.
author: Daniel Y.

description:
Honestly, if I had to rate their food, I would give it 1 star. Their food was somewhere between okay to bad. The soft tofu soup tasted pretty yummy, but it seemed like they used firm tofu instead. I usually like soft tofu soup because they just sorta melt in your mouth since it is so soft, but theirs was a different story. Our deukbokki (or however u spell it) was soooo dry that the vermicelli noodle was literally stuck together. You could stab your fork and lift up like the whole thing -_-. We got the kimchi fried rice as well, which was very normal. 
I wanted to give 3 stars though because I truly felt bad seeing the old lady host, take orders, serve, cook, and bus tables all by herself. Me and my bf couldn't stop feeling bad while eating there. There was literally no one else working but her! I don't know if she is the owner, but i hope they do fix that problem.
author: Verdina P.

description: I have nothing bad to say about this place. ordered the Kal Bi, Bul Go ki and beef bi bim bop. I would say the kal bi was just average. Not bad but nothing special. The bi bim bop and bul go ki were delicious though! My family and I were the only one's there and it was super empty though ): maybe people were just home for the World Series game.. Also, the lady who worked there was super nice and got our food prepped right away!
author: Holly P.

description: The food was DELICIOUS! It tasted homemade. The place, on the other hand is not all that. It is devoid of decorations and more than a bit on the dirty side. The walls had grease and food sprinkled from previous patrons and the bathroom seat was broken. While all this added to the "hole in the wall" feel, some soap and water and pictures on the wall would improve the place significantly. This is good food, but definitely not for the finicky patron.
author: Jeannette T.

description:
Oh dear God, the Be Bim Bap was so good!I

I was craving good Korean food and took the hike from Napa to Outer Richmond SF for it thanks to good Yelp ratings and it was exactly what I was hoping for!

I am a FAN for sure!
author: Kristen W.

description: Delicious food! Had the Kimchee Fried Rice, and loved the free accompaniments that went along perfectly. Would be 5 stars but the service was a bit slow... Probably because last night was a one woman show for the whole place, but power to her! Will be back to try the other recommendations.
author: Valerie K.

description: Came here looking for a new yummy Korean spot. The food is very tasty and nothing bad about it. They didn't have our favorite spicy pork that night so the dinner just felt incomplete for me. But the ahjumma there is very sweet and makes you feel right at home. It was only her there and a couple tables so we had to wait while she runs back n forth. Lovely little clean place that I think everyone would enjoy.
author: Laylay B.

description: Honestly, the food here wasn't good but the service was. I personally felt like this place was over-hyped so when I came here for dinner, the food was pretty disappointing. The seafood pancake did not have much flavor (recommend going to Toyose for that) and the chef's special soup was super salty. Decided to give them three stars because the waitress was super friendly. Free refills on the mini appetizers like every Korean restaurant in the city but unfortunately, even the kimchi didn't taste good. Wouldn't recommend coming here if you want delicious Korean food. If you're not picky about Korean food, then this place should be fine for you.
author: Monica C.

description: Not only was the food good (the best seafood pancake and sautéed squid) but we were so impressed with service being it was only her taking care of the front AND doing all the prep/cooking. You could see right into the kitchen and there wasn't anyone back there (except when she went in after taking orders). We were happy to be there to support, and absolutely recommend you do too.
author: Ana S.

description:
