Wow nothing feels more like a family run restaurant than looking into the service window and watching the woman make your food. This was our third attempt at finding Korean food since Muguboka on Balboa was closed, and Han Il Kwan had too long of a wait.

BANCHAN:
I really enjoyed the banchan here. They only gave 6 dishes, but they were quality ones and I enjoyed all of them. We did have to ask for refills, which was alright.

SERVICE: 
A bit slow. There was one server tending to five tables. Don't hesitate to ask for anything.

FOOD:
Two girlfriends and I shared:
- 2 Spicy Tofu Soups with Beef: Unfortunately they only have one level of spiciness -- spicy. I didn't mind, I like it spicy, but my friends were a bit disappointed they didn't have any options. They were able to handle it though. They add the raw egg and also came with two bowls of rice.
- Japchae: It was good. Nothing mindblowing fantastic.

The food was good. I'd be back if I'm ever in the area and not looking to wait a long time.
author: Jenna H.

description: Came here on a Friday night and ordered beef bul go ki and some rice bowls. Both were great and we actually ended up ordering more bul go ki because we couldn't get enough. The woman running the place was great; really quick service and very helpful.
author: Krista V.

description:
The best Korean restaurant in the city. Period.

I seriously thought everything tasted like how my mom used to make it. It was shocking how comforting and familiar all the dishes were.  I guess it makes sense because the literal translation of the restaurant is "Mom's hands."
author: Richard S.

description:
Ordered:

Soft Tofu Soup With Beef: 3/5 This wasn't bad. The tofu came in solid pieces which was different from most other Korean restaurants. When I asked for an extra egg they said they put it in the soup already which was weird because I neither saw nor tasted it. This doesn't come with rice by the way!  

Kimchi Fried Rice: 3/5 Nothing extraordinary about this dish, it's your typical kimchi fried rice. 

Service: 2/5 I was the only one in the restaurant when I came. The lady who serviced me seemed to be really nice in the beginning but when I asked for rice (because my tofu soup didn't come with any) and to refill my side dishes, she gave me loads of attitude. I could hear her swearing under her breath. It was also really hard getting her attention in the first place because she sat with her back facing me at the counter. I felt like she ignored me when I tried getting her attention, I had to continually raise my voice after each "Excuse me?" until she finally turned around. 

Overall, nothing really spectacular about this place. There are better Koreans restaurants in the area that you can go to.
author: Courtni W.

description: Okay, now i know where to go when i want comforting spicy tofu soup, bulgogi, and spicy rice cakes. This restaurant is a cozy spot for a warm meal. I've never seen a line form outside either. My usual go to spot for soon du bu is My Tofu House (further into the Inner Richmond) and unfortunately they normally have a bit of a wait list. When i'm hungry, i am HUNGRY. I'd happily come back to Um Ma Son. It's still hard for me to accept the bay area prices after eating kbbq for very decent prices in southern cali for several years. This restaurant is no different but i don't mind paying a few extra bucks when the staff works so hard. Now... If i wanted to drink heavy amounts of soju and soak it up with delicious korean food then i would go elsewhere.
author: Samantha L.

description: Looking for late night dinner to eat and found this place. Had some spicy rice cake dish and a vegetarian tofu soup with my bed friend. It's decent. I like the rice cake dish thing we got, which I'm not sure what it's called but it's #34 on the menu. I normally don't eat spicy food but the food is pretty decent here! Will come back again!
author: Yulin K.

description:
Might have been the dishes we got, but this place is eh compared to other Korean restaurants in the city. We got a traditional korean soup (MSG overload) and bibimbap... Side dishes were eh and they were so busy we never got refills!

While I appreciate small owned restaurants, this place is pretty inefficient. It's a two person operation (and reading from past reviews realized my experience isn't different) and the woman in the front (while working very hard) seems so overwhelmed that I just feel bad eating there.
author: Laura H.

description: It is really ran by an old korean lady. She's pretty nice but super busy because she's managing all the tables. The food is a little saltier than I would like. We got the beef tofu soup and there wasn't a lot of beef and there but the tofu chunks were pretty huge. The japchae was alright as well. They both were salty. The banchan was good. She would refill it but she didn't look too happy about that either. We would go again if we want korean food and don't want to wait in line like all those other korean places.
author: Jessica H.

description:
Highlights: 
- Tofu Beef Soup.Even when I got only white tofu soup without any spiciness. Huge chunks of silky tofu, sliced pieces of beef and flavored really well. It came with a bowl of white rice and it was perfect. (Rounding my review up because of this!)
- 6 different side dishes (fish cake, kimchi, bean sprouts, spicy bean sprouts, mini fish, and pickled cucumbers)
- Never crowded nor have I had to wait each time I came. 

Improvements: 
- The side dishes lacked in quality. I felt the cucumber dish was too salty and the regular bean sprouts tasted old. 
- Service is pretty slow due to the lack of workers. There weren't many people in the restaurant anyways, but no one to be found as they were all too busy inside the kitchen or doing other things in the back. 
- Did I just see a grandpa change one of his grand kids diaper on one of the tables?! I did and that was not cool. I know there aren't that many people in the restaurant, but that's what your car let alone the bathroom is for!

Tips: 
- Accepts credit cards
- Best to get your food To Go.
author: Tracy T.

description:
No, definitely not the best seafood pancake. Seven hungry girls circled for half an hour around Geary to find parking to eat here after venturing on yelp for a good Korean spot to hit. One of our girls was craving seafood pancake. 

Consensus of the group was not good. I can say this with confidence because amongst the 7 of us, we ordered half the menu + beer + yogurt soju. 

Lets start with the alcohol (of course!!) -- This definitely isn't a place to drink at. Although they have Cass and OB beer (essentials of a korean restaurant. if they don't serve this at your korean place, get out. get out now!), their yogurt soju is lacking. It was way too sweet and lacked alcohol content. Not to mention, the bottle was small and we had to  ordered so many just to stay hydrated ..ironic but true. hydrated. 

Foodwise:
Kimchee fried rice - super bland, and not enough kimchee. All there was was red pasty rice with chopped white onion. Where is the kimchee?
They must make their own kimchee, because it doesn't seem fermented long enough to have the right acidic taste. There literally was no taste to it; it was just red paste slapped on lettuce leaves. 

Kimchee soup - terrible. Salty, red pasted onion filled terribleness. Because we didn't get any water, I dumped tea into my soup twice to make it more watery and soup-like. 

Seafood pancake - average, too doughy and not enough content for my taste. There should be more green onion, and more seafood!

Chicken wings- average. Really average. 

Bulgogi - Ok, pretty flavorful, and probably the best thing we got. 

The side dishes were tiny, and we had to ask for them to be refilled. A lot of the expected flavors in Korean food just wasn't quite there at this place. I always think that if it was a legit Korean restaurant, a ton of Koreans would be there eating. That's when I feel satisfied I'm having an authentic experience. I noticed there were no korean people that came to eat in the 4 hour time frame that we were there. The food was ok to munch on, as we caught up on college days and drank our beers, but "Meh, I've had better."
author: Joanna S.

description:
I ended up at Um Ma Son after I attempted to go to Han Il Kwan and left because a tour bus had arrived. I left unimpressed.

As far as I could tell, Um Ma Son was staffed by an older lady, who served as both the waitress and chef. As a result, the wait for food was very long - we sat around swatting at flies for what felt like eternity for our food to come out. I ordered a spicy tofu soup, kim chee fried rice, and beef short ribs, which my table wanted to share family-style, and it was a bit of an ordeal to acquire extra utensils for serving the food. As for the food, it was very greasy. All over our dishes were covered with a red, unappetizing oil at the end of our meal.

All may have been forgiven, except that the restaurant is quite expensive and I expected better for the price ($30/person). For your Korean food fix, I would advise going to Han Il Kwan, Manna, or Hahn's Hibachi.
author: Sidney L.

description:
Just finished dinner here on a Sunday night. My boyfriend and I walked in a little after 10:30pm. There were not a lot of options on their menu compared to other Korean restaurants. He ordered a Bim Bi Bap and I ordered some rice cake with beef in soup.  Bim bi bap is suppose to come in a stone pot but it came out in a regular ceramic bowl with the egg already cooked on top. The veggies and rice were cold after mixing everything and had little flavor.  My rice cake soup was alright, it just satisfied my hunger. They only gave us 4 banchans (side dishes), which is very little compared  to other Korean places. I had higher expectations since it is a 4 start on yelp... 
This place also closes at 12am.. but they started to clean everything up, turned off the open sign and locked their doors just a little after a 11pm.
author: Mei Z.

description:
Seriously,
Yelp fooled me big time on this one.
I don't know if it's just a one-time thing, but all the food I've had that night was bland.
I've had the Kal Bi, Kim Chee Fried Rice and the Tofu Soup. And all of them could really use some more seasoning.
No I meant A LOT more seasoning.
My friend agreed with me on that, so it's not because my palate was numb.
Not sure if I should come back to confirm my review.
author: Alan T.

description:
My friend and I came here on a Friday at 7pm.  The restaurant was not busy all, only two tables..I was kinda hesitate about that.....Anyway, since we were there, we just tried it and turned out not bad.

The service was friendly, warm and efficient (even though only two people worked that night).  

We ordered:

Seafood Pancake (small) - The pancake was pretty good.  Flavorful with a lot of ingredients and not oily.  

Pork Belly - The portion was smaller than other Korean restaurants. The taste was tasty and rich.

Tofu Soup - The soup was decent.  Very standard taste.

The compliment Banchan were all good.  I like the fishcake the most.
author: Liza T.

description:
I love the woman that owns this place.
I love her pajun.
I love her talking in Korean to me.
I love her smile.
I love her soon tubu chigae (extra spicy).

Yay. Support her. She's got the best pajun in the city (Korean pancake).
author: Maria A.

description:
Great neighborhood spot. Korean BBQ is my jam. We have eaten here twice already and have gotten take out as well.

We ordered the Kal Bi and the seafood pancake (small) to share between two people. Super flavorful that I am salivating typing this out.

Very friendly service - sweet older Korean lady who probably owns the place.
author: Alex P.

description:
Got Kim chi fried rice to go...umma was eating dinner but went into kitchen to cook, which I felt bad about.  People are nice here..but fried rice wasn't that great. Lumpy rice is a no no in fried rice country. Egg on top did not have the runny yolk at all, in fact, yolk was broken and cooked to a well done. 
Sorry umma, I'm spoiled
author: Linda T.

description:
Came here a couple weeks ago on Friday night. My Tofu House will still be my favorite Korean restaurant.

I ordered the bulgoki and babe ordered the dumplings/potstickers and the kimchee fried rice. The bulgoki was a-okay no wow factor or anything and the dumplings/potstickers were more like wontons minus the wonton soup. Babe's kimchee didn't have much wow factor to it either.

3 stars for the food and 3.5 for the service.
author: Mabel Y.

description:
Even though it's a small restaurant, the two women working seemed really frazzled. I was scared to ask them for anything, and it took forever for us to order. 

I was really craving a spicy kimchi tofu soup, and since I don't eat land animals I got the veggie one. When it came, it was a lot different than I'm used to - the soup was really watery, the veggies weren't exciting (a few mushrooms and zucchini), and it came with no rice. No egg on top either. I tried asking for one so I could crack it on top, but they looked at me like I was crazy. Not impressed at all. 

Seafood pancake was pretty tasty though. 

The chicken and pork on the sizzling plates looked appetizing as my brother guzzled them down. 

I might go back for the bibimbap, but not the tofu soup.
author: Denise H.

description: Cute little restaurant. The girls and I came by here after hiking in the city and we were starving. There was a sweet lady at the front that helped us right away. We ordered seafood pancakes, bulgogi, and a soup (rice cake?). Everything was pretty tasty. My favorite was the seafood pancakes cuz it didn't seem too oily.. They also had a good variety of side dishes. I'll probably be back if I'm ever in the area :)
author: Jenn N.

description: Amazing food and service!  We had a table for 10 so we ordered practically everything!  I particularly liked the bibimbap, BBQ pork and the beef stew!  They cook from the heart.  Very unassuming place with incredible service.  We'll be back!
author: Robert L.

description: Delicious food! Great service. Love the kimchi pancake and the tofu soup. Would definitely recommend coming here. The decor is nothing overly fancy, but the deliciousness of the food redeems it. They also give many different types of authentic kimchi to start which is much better than many other planes.
author: Ilana S.

description: This place might be a bit small. But the food are really good any spicy! I love it spicy and the price are alright. Service is good, I think they are a family owned resturant.
author: Christopher G.

description:
Whenever my friends get a craving for some Korean soju cocktails, there's only a handful of places in the city to go to.  Toyose is the natural default for us, but without a reservation, good luck with the wait when you drop in.  Playground and Arang are our good alternatives, but they usually draw a crowd as well (haven't been to The Spot yet either, but I know it's busy there too).  Thankfully, there's this hidden little gem in the outer Richmond that can offer those drinks and more without any hassles.

Driving down Geary, it's pretty easy to just blow right by Um Ma Son without even seeing it.  However, should you happen upon it, you'll find a modest, cozy little place that serves some solid food.  The Dolsot Bibimbap is pretty good - good mix and serving size of veggies and meat.  Similarly, their haemul pajun (seafood pancake) is one of the better ones, considering how it's loaded with fillings and not too batter-heavy.  I think the one at Muguboka has a slight edge, but it's still really good here, so no complaints.

On the flip side, the Kimchi Fried Rice is a little uneven for me; the first time I had it was decent, but the most recent time it tasted a little off.  In either case though, there was a noticeable lack of beef, so that doesn't make me want to try it again.  Also, they have pictures on the wall of fried chicken on the menu, but when we tried to order some with our drinks, we couldn't tell if she was saying they were just out, or if don't have wings in general.  Oh well.

There's a couple of other specialty house dishes they offer that were pretty good, but I can't remember their exact names.  However, the most notable one was the order of braised beef ribs with potatoes and carrot.  The meat was really flavorful, and I loved the sauce.  They give you a decent selection of banchan, but I feel like they used to offer more.  However, the last couple of trips here, the waitress gave our table a free plate of steamed dumplings, so I'm more than willing to make that trade!  And speaking of which, the service has always been friendly and nice.  There's never been a wait either, so we've never had a problem getting a table or feeling rushed out.  Throw in those soju cocktails and their late hours, and Um Ma Son is great spot to lay low and still get some solid Korean food and drinks.
author: Mike L.

description:
i've had better, but i'm still giving them 4 stars... they stay open late. and the service is really friendly and down to earth. the little lady in the kitchen is super cute and she whips out the food really quickly! the ban chan is pretty much the same as manna on irving. 

i'm a bit sad because they ran out of chicken wings and potstickers. :( the seafood pancake was pretty good. not crispy enough though. the steamed dumplings were good, but i feel like it wasn't tender enough. i ordered the tofu soup with beef and that was yum yum good! i asked for mild, but there was still a kick to it. when they brought it out to the table, it was still bubbling for 10 minutes. until i was just about done, my soup was still super hot! i love that! babe ordered the kimchee fried rice. it was ok... he had better. i think it was because he asked for mild, and it came out super spicy. and also, the egg was overcooked. 

the bill came out to be about $70 for the 4 of us... which isn't too shabby! hopefully, next time - they'll have the chicken wangs!
author: Ann T.

description:
Midnight in SF and a mad Korean craving strikes. You're drunk, tired, and all you want to do is shove some food down your whine-hole. Solution: Um Ma Son!

This place was mostly empty when we rolled in but filled up and got banaynays after 12ish. Regardless, we were served & fooded in a timely fashion. We started with some generous banchan - tasty, as usual, and decided to get the man du, hae mul pa jun, fried chicken wings, and bi bim bop to share. Of those, I have to say - the seafood pancake was SO. FLIPPIN'. GOOD. Like, one of the best I've ever had. Perfectly fried and loaded up with all the good shit. The man du were also good, nice thin wrappers. The KFC wasn't sauced (booo, I love gochujang) but were crispy and big and pretty good anyway. The bi bim bop was...bi bim bop? It wasn't super impressive, but it was solid. But whatever, man. How many places can fix your midnight Korean jones? Not too many, and Um Ma Son does it well.
author: Corinna K.

description: Food is very delicious better than other Korean restaurants. Seafood pancakes, soups, is like everything. Very nice service, even very nice sometimes on the house soda. Love it I should give an extra star.
author: Victor C.

description:
This restaurant sure is cray cray because every time I go, there is only ONE lady cooking. My friends and I always notice this. And get this, she's also the server, so it's a one "wo"man show!

The quality of the food is great - I still don't know how she juggles cooking and serving - it's quite amazing. I've been here multiple times and I have to say the seafood pancake, various marinated meats, jap chae, bi bim bap, soon du bu, are great. Your stomach will leave happayyy.
author: Julie H.

description:
U gh, I want to really like this spot -- decent food, open til 2am, nice owner
M y biggest gripe: for the portions you get, it's overpriced

M y favorite here is the fluffy and delicious Seafood Pancake
A verage tasting Kalbi and Kim Chee Fried Rice -- good but not great

S low on weeknights, I presume -- it was completely empty on a Tuesday
O ne person was working, a nice old lady who served, cooked, and bussed
N ot sure if I'd come again for dinner, but it makes a nice late night option
author: Anthony N.

description: What attracted me here: one of the few places that has Kim Chee fried rice. I came here a few times and I've tried their soon dooboo soup, bibimbap, but have yet to try Kim Chee fried rice because my bf doesn't like it. which is fine, because it gives me more reasons to come back. the bibimbap rice was perfectly crispy. the fixings inside were fresh, flavorful, and crunchy. the soup was light, spicy, and had great tofu. um ma is also sweet and tries her best to serve you even when its busy. m
author: Connie C.

description:
A litttle more expensive than I'm used to paying for a Korean spot, but this place is so CUTE and the owner is adorable! You feel like her child when you eat here - she is so sweet and treats you like family.

We had the seafood pancake - YUM! and HUGE!
Spicy pork - yum
chap chae - yum x2

Apparently it isn't open as late as when I went here, but still open pretty late (until 12am)! Cuz who wants to eat Jack In The Box all the time on those late nights? Not this girl. I prefer some good home cookin!
author: Tay R.

description:
This place is a one man show. I'm sure it can't be this way every night but during my visit, I watched the owner greet, take orders, serve hot barley tea, cook, serve dishes, bus tables and run the dishes through the washer. And she managed to do this seamlessly without going insane. Our food arrived in no time and there were a few other parties sitting inside the restaurant as well. 

We were disappointed they ran out of the ddukbokki when dropped by specifically for that but we ordered the following:
-kimchi fried rice served with an egg and nori bits 
-kimchi pancakes
-bibimbap served in a clay pot that came out piping HOT creating the crackly semi-burnt rice that we love so much in no time. 

This was a lot for two so we packed up the leftovers and the hubs promised to eat it for lunch the next day. 

I'm glad this place stays opened til 2am. I guess I'll be heading out towards the Richmond the next time I get a late night Korean food craving.
author: Esther A.

description:
Late night Korean oasis!  The hardworking women of Um Ma Son turn out some great treats and stay open until 2am, long after most restaurants fold up.  That's what I call customer service!  

Seafood pancake - best I've had in San Francisco.  Loaded with great seafood and veg and fried just right - delicate, not burnt.  Dumplings were silky, delicate and haunting.  Solid be bim bap.  Chicken wings were crispy.  I was hoping they'd sauce them and fire them up a bit, but good nonetheless.

Prices are fair, not sure why other reviewers are complaining.  Without alcohol we would have tabbed at under $50 for four.
author: Bob K.

description:
Cheaper prices by a few bucks compared to other Korean joints in the same vicinity.
I think the fried chicken is myth. They always seem to "run out" of it, even when the restaurant just opened. I think it's just not on the menu anymore.
The staples: bulgogi, kimchi fried rice, kimchi pancake, bibimbap... are all solid and good.
author: Mercutio k.

description:
Went to this place on a Sunday night 5/24. 
Yelped places that were open late and ended up coming here because it was nearby and closed at 12am. Arrived and seated once we entered at about 10:45pm. 
Sat for a few minutes before waitress came to take our order. I ordered the bibimbap because nothing else seemed appetizing. Most korean places that serve bibimbap usually come in a stone/clay pot and sizzling hot. Mine came in a regular large bowl with crumbs of meat, a fried egg and a bunch of cold veggies. On the side the waitress gave me a bowl of rice like in the usual metal bowl so i thought that was their way of doing a bibimbap and dumped my rice into the large bowl. Everything was so hard to eat because it was cold and I hate eating beansprouts raw. At least with a stone pot it would have cooked a little. I understand that I came in an hour+ before closing and that they probably didn't want to heat up a stone pot anymore, but if i had known that they wouldn't be serving it in the stone pot then i don't think i would've ordered it. It would have been nice if she had just told me so i would order something else. I doubt i'll give this place a second chance.
author: Andy Y.

description: I came here on a weekday for dinner around 6pm and there was no body. Only the old lady and us where there to share the emptiness of this place. She was really nice and cooked very quickly as well. But the tofu soup was meh... Definitely not flavorful enough (I have been to Korea. Twice.) The place is pretty small and smelled somewhat odd when you first enter. I wanted to give it a 2 star but she was really nice. Maybe I should give it another try?
author: Shirley F.

description: I love the food here and think the woman who runs it is very nice. I like how she says thank you in Korean when you leave. I give her credit for doing so much herself. The food is very tasty!
author: Chris B.

description:
I can't help singing the praises of tiny restaurants with friendly staff and tasty, well-priced food. Um Ma Son is spot on by all accounts. You are greeted with a friendly "Annyong haseyo!" when you enter. The space is tiny, adding to the cosy feeling initiated by the warm and attentive staff. 

Banchan is good and refills are gladly given (who can ever be satisfied with just one tiny dish of kimchi?) Bi bim bap and its tasty cousin dol sot bibim bap (this one cooked in a stone pot which makes the bottom layer of rice deliciously crispy) both hit the spot.

If you're in the mood for homey Korean food, Um Ma Son is a great choice.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Awesome food, quick service, open late.
We had the pot stickers, kim chee fried rice with beef, and one of the dishes with fried rice and egg in the stone pot. We were the only ones there, so everything was very fast and the price was very reasonable as well.
author: Karthik K.

description:
After an evening with a few friends being tricked into thinking we were going to see a Chinese cultural dance show but instead were subjected to Falungong propaganda (really shady business going on there, Shen Yun), we were not only pissed beyond belief but (to make matters worse) starving as well. The line at Purple Kow was way too long, so we ended up walking in search of a Korean place that was open (this was around probably 11 PM). Walking past George Washington High School, we finally arrived at Um Ma Son (Mama's Hands?) and were (surprisingly) warmly welcomed (unlike that OTHER Korean place that turned us away an hour before their reported closing time...)

We were immediately seated, brought tea and water, and our order was taken very promptly, but not hurriedly so. The waitress and who I assumed was the jumo were very courteous the entire time. We ordered a seafood pancake and most of us ordered a stone pot bibimbap. I initially wanted just a regular bibimbap, but the waitress insisted it would not be any extra trouble or take much longer to have it stone pot style. Yay!

The banchan was immediately brought out and dutifully refilled throughout our meal. The selection was typical, tasted great, and just what we wanted: assorted greens, bean sprouts, fish cake, kimchi, kakddugi, spicy pickled cucumbers, the works. By no means your typical 20-dish spread you'd find in an LA Korean place, but who needs black beans anyways?

The seafood pancake came out extremely well - I believe it's this place's specialty. Crispy on the outside, soft and chewy on the inside, not too greasy either. The seafood was spread pretty evenly and was not lacking either. The stone pot bibimbap was pretty hefty on the vegetables without a whole lot of meat, but that's pretty typical. With regards to the food here, it's your typical above-average Korean place (I don't know if that makes sense to you, but it's best way I could put it). 

The main reason this place gets 4 stars instead of just 3 is the surprisingly courteous service we received! We more or less expected to be greeted with scowls for coming out so late (as we were the only patrons other than a couple next to us who was having a lovely-smelling hotpot situation going on - not meant to sound like a sex thing), but much to our delight, the service was very courteous and fantastic. We definitely felt like we were being taken care of, and the service and food live up to the restaurant's name.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Everything about a family-run ethnic restaurant just makes me want to hug the staff and the concept. My date and I were on the prowl for some super authentic Korean food and Yelp pointed us in this direction. Past all the other obvious choices along Geary, we went all the way to 23rd for some Um Ma Son.

At 7:30 on a rainy Friday night, we were the only other table aside from the Chinese women sharing soju and gabbing away giddily. The Korean lady who took our order was warm, sweet and exactly the person you'd hope to find at a K-spot. 

The sides came out and did their job in piquing our already ravenous appetite and after the piping hot clay bowl arrived filled with bibimbap, we devoured. Awesome, amazing, authentic and then some. Then the bean paste soup showed up and everything about this bubbling fermented beauty satisfied. 

On a rainy night, there might not be a more hospitable and hearty option than Um Ma Son!
author: Monica S.

description:
I am so happy to find the fried chicken wings on their menu, finally!   yay!  I love korean style fried chicken.  She does an amazing job.
She has my favorite goki soondubu and dol sot bibimbap.
service is excellent.  she used to be a one woman operation.  no longer.  she got a girl to help her out.  always welcomed with a warm hello.  i feel like i came home after a long day at work.

parking can be iffy.  there are a couple of restaurants on the same block.
if you plant to come here "late night" make sure you call ahead.  sometimes she does close early.

ENJOY...
author: Elisa O.

description:
We came here late on a Fri or Saturday night...maybe around 1030 or so. Parking was nice and convenient but the place was packed. We had to wait about 10 minutes to get a table. It was fine because I had to walk the baby to sleep.  

Once we got our table we decided to get the seafood pancake (small) and two soondubus. 

The pancake was on hit. Loved it. The banchans (sp) were good too. 

The soup was good...I liked it. I wish I saw them crack the egg in it though...nothing major but I just like seeing that. I asked them for an egg and they said it was already in there. 

When I pass by this place on the weekdays, it's empty. I don't know how busy it gets, maybe later in the night or something, but I have never really seen this place packed...maybe super late night hours since this is open til 2am.
author: Leena C.

description:
Unfortunately, "Mother's Hand" includes a few pieces of carrots that have the old 'towel smell'.  I'm pretty sure it's a one-off thing since their health score is pretty high.

Other than that, the food was pretty darn good, it was 4.5 stars until I hit those smelly carrots.  :(
author: Koalie W.

description:
I can't exactly give it 4 or even 5 stars as I was waiting there with my sister on the table for a good while before anyone asked us for our orders. The restaurant wasn't terribly busy at all. The food made up for it though. I wanted to order their steamed fish (which takes 15 minutes to prepare, according to the menu), but the lady, in her limited English, told me that since it's my 1st time here, I should order something else. She suggested the "pancake" appetizer and a noodle dish with beef and vegetables. That dish had very little meat on it though. We also ordered Yogurt Soju too which tasted very good. Almost close to the "Yakult" drinks you can get at the Asian supermarkets. If I wasn't careful, I could probably drink one jug.

As a side note, the lady handed the receipt to me in the Japanese way (with 2 hands) and thanked me in Japanese which I thought was kind of strange and humorous as I never spoke to her in Japanese at the restaurant.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
I love this place.  This place serves what my Korean boyfriend calls "Korean street food".  What?  Let me explain.  So generally Korean restaurants serve tofu soup, bi bim bap, chop chae, and various barbeque meat dishes.  This place serves that, but MORE.  

Kim Chi Fried Rice: WOW!  Moist fried rice with beef and a beautiful fried egg on top.  Each piece of rice is covered with red kimchi sauce.  This was a hit at our table.

Fried Chicken Wings:  Something about the batter.  So crunchy, with just the right amount f seasoning.  The meat was so juicy.  

Seafood Pancake:  I just can't get enough of this dish.  Although it's made with flour, it didn't taste heavy.  Lots of substance in this huge group-friendly appetizer!

Spicy Rice Cake with Pork:  Initially I though I was ordering ddukbokki, but it's slightly different.  Unlike ddukbokki, this dish is not sweet, but has a "pickled" flavor.  I still enjoyed it nonetheless.  

Service here is great.  Both times I dined here the two ladies treated us like we were guests in their home.  They completely lit up when my boyfriend spoke to them in Korean:)  They remind me of adorable grandmas:)

Tip:  They open until 2AM!  Next time I need a late night bite I know exactly where to go.  Um Ma Son!!!
author: Gloria Y.

description: I would not go here again.  Small portions. Over priced. Slow terrible service.  They had 2 people working for the entire restaurant.  Granted it's a small mom and pop shop with about a handful of tables, but the restaurant was filled around 730pm.  Service and quality of food greatly suffered.  The main waitress was very stressed and she made everyone aware.  It was like watching a bad replay of Diner Dash.  I saw a couple walk out because their patience ran out.  She would slam the plates down and her anxiety made us feel very uncomfortable.  I felt like a child and listening to my parents argue.  The other lady was a boss (props) and doubled as the chef and waitress but the results was noticeable in the food.   Most of our meal was overcooked.  It was probably the worst kalbi I've ever had.  Dry, shriveled, lackluster meat.  And WTF over $20 for that little meat???  The seafood pancake was decent.  The dok bok ki was missing a certain flavor and were not in the usual shape of a round stick.  The mackerel was ridiculously oily and overdone.  It was one of the rare times that I had food leftover and did not ask for a to go box.  You will not see me here again.
author: Tammy N.

description:
I went here for two reasons: I was craving Tofu Soup like nobody's business and my friend had never had Korean food before.  This was the closest place to us, so hey, why not? 

The vegetables that they give with meals in small side dishes were delicious, but I have not ever had a bad vegetable experience at a Korean restaurant.  My friend had the BBQ Chicken and was unimpressed, but she enjoyed the vegetables and rice.  I was SO excited for my Tofu Soup, but it came out a light orange color...I asked for spicy.  Maybe they went easy on the spice because I'm not Korean?  Even though Japanese usually can't, I can handle my spicy food.  When I asked if they could make it hotter, the waitress looked at me and giggled slightly while taking it to the kitchen.  It came back a darker shade of orange, but it really did not hit the spot; I too stuck to the rice and veggies.

Next time (if there is a next time) I will show them my best serious face and demand spicy.
author: Jessyca M.

description:
I've been meaning to write a review for this place but to life's events mixed with some laziness I never got around to it. So here's my quick review, and my first one! Woot!

I came here several times. I found out about it on Yelp to. When I read a sweet old Korean lady ran this place herself I had to see I came here. I brought family and friends and each time I came I was greeted with a warm smile like I was family and she was my distant grandma I don't get to visit so often. 

When you order the food its made and served at a decent pace. What do you expect though she runs the entire restaurant HERSELF! Amazing. I don't know how old she is but at her age managing, waiting tables, and cooking...WoW.

Food is really good. Tastes like family cooked meals made by a loving mother. My mother is the best cook in my opinion but this lady's cooking reminds me of my mom's love in her cooking. Yes I'm a momma's boy. 

Prices are typical of a Korean restaurant a little steep but quality dishes. I wish i had a job so I could afford coming back here more often. 

I try to spread the word how great this place is by dragging friends and family here. Its that great! 

I really hope this restaurant really does well and becomes a staple like the other popular Korean restaurants in the Richmond district. Maybe its because of my obsession with Korean culture (Hallyu) I would like to see more of a Korean restaurants in SF.
author: Jude N.

description:
10PM late night dinner with a couple friends..

They didn't have a lot of stuff to offer that was on the menu. There was only one lady working, so I guess that's why. Ended up ordering the soup with rice cakes and pork. There.. wasn't a lot of pork. Rice cakes? They were okay. Some of them weren't cooked long enough and were hard. Soup base was good, though. However, do note that it's just soup. Not tofu soup with rice. Just. Soup. Yeah, I made that mistake. I wanted tofu soup with rice and I ended up getting just soup. With no tofu or rice. 
Nice lady, though. At least they're open till 3am.
author: Leslie C.

description: If you want to experience what Korean family food is like at home, this is the place. Banchan (side dishes) were amazing. Had a spicy beef soup that was so good. It was as if my mom made it for me. Two thumbs up.
author: Silin N.

description:
For some reason, I didn't realize that this place wasn't a "BBQ your own food" type of place so that was a surprise. No big deal though. 

It's a small place but I called ahead for my group of 8 on Friday night and the nice lady on the phone said it was no problem. The food was good - banchan, pancake, pork, kalbi, bulgogi, spicy bulgogi, kim chee soup. 

Two ladies are really nice. They even gave us a free Cass beer. Not much going on in terms of ambiance though but solid eating experience. I would probably try other Korean places before coming back here just yet, but the wonderfully nice ladies make me happy to patronize this place.

The biggest pain was trying to find parking on Friday night. I seriously circled the blocks for about 20 minutes. If you can avoid driving on Fri/Sat night, you'll save your sanity. 

After dinner, we walked to Joe's for ice cream - yummy in ma tummy.
author: Veronica H.

description:
I'm not an Asian food person. Bleh. Not at all. BUTTT some guy that I was hanging out with wanted BBQ so we scoped out a Korean place...(Korean? Bbq? Um, ok???) Anyway, I yelped it and saw this place had great reviews.

I got the #17 and maybe its just bc I am a Southern super white girl, I did not like it whatsoever. I don't even remember if I ate anything other than the noodles...which were hard to pick around with all the sh*t on top. I'm sure it would be good for someone that likes it...but this is my review so 2 stars for you, Um Ma Son BBQ place!
author: Cally L.

description: um ma son dishes out some great korean food (with complimentary banchan!). some of my favorites are the hae mul pa jun (seafood pancake), kim chee duk bok um (sauteed kim chee, pork and rice cake), duk guk (rice cake soup with beef, egg and green onion) and the kalbi (short ribs). typically when i come in, there is only one woman working who takes orders, cooks the food and serves the food. pretty amazing how efficient they are given that it's one person doing everything.
author: Jae C.

description:
This is a long overdue review.  I have been a very happy customer for a very long time and I just simply love the food and the very nice owner lady!   She never laughs at me when I use my very very bad Korean on her, a major plus! 
The service has always been great, the food is extremely tasty and homey (just like mom's hands :)) I have brought friends and I had hosted party here.    They never disappoint I look forward to many more years of yummy food at Um Ma Son!
Cheers!
author: Jeni F.

description: Just down the street from my place. I like to come here when I'm craving for Korean food nearby. The food is very good and I've tried a couple of nearby Korean places that were not as great and a little pricier. This place looks more hole in the wall, but overall the food is pretty good and the prices are reasonable. The service was good the number of times I've gone.
author: Grant O.

description: Service was mediocre, but it was justifiable after Outside Lands with only one waitress (the other one scheduled to work had car troubles) and a packed restaurant. They did apologize several times for the wait and promptly refilled our banchan later in the night, so I'm not docking them on service. Also the food was delicious.
author: Orien W.

description:
Um Ma Son is a mid-size Korean restaurant ran by two women. The service here is amazing even though there's only two of them. They come by once in a while to see how things are going and if the food was good. It's a great atmosphere that's not seen in some other restaurants.

They serve the regularly found Korean food such as the BBQ meats, tofu soup, bibimbap, korean fried chicken, kimchi pancake, etc. 

Bulgogi was nicely cooked by the women. Soft and tender beef were used and the marinade is great. 

Kimchi Pancake was filled with big pieces of kimchi inside. The pancake wasn't spicy and had the sauce to go with it. I didn't like how there was big pieces of kimchi inside the pancake, but it was nicely fried to a good crisp. 

Then there are the regular side dishes offered and also rice. The restaurant has quite a few selection of soju to drink. They accept Master and Visa credit cards here.
author: Steven B.

description: Cosy family-run diner. Good food, too little selection to choose from. Friendly staffs.
author: Joelle K.

description:
Hrm.. late night, the best time for me to go out and have something to eat or look for cause I do love the nightlife. its something expected from me.

I came out here case I wanted to swap up and try something that I haven't  had out of a Korean restaurant. I haven't really been out to one since I was with a couple of korean friends a couple years ago so I decided to go eat here. At first I was thinking of getting to a hotpot but I'll do that another time since that seems more like having to be with more that a couple people to enjoy. 

What to expect / what I had:

- Seafood Paejun
- Seafood Dolsot Bibimbap
- bottle of Hite

Well there was only one waitress and the owner which I think is a lady that ran the kitchen but man does she cook!!! Extremely well, considering the fact that I went out here on a solo mission. It wasn't a very crowded place and the setting was nice. When I came in the lady greeted me with a smile and had me sit anywhere I wanted. There was a couple that was in the restaurant before I was there other than that it was a well relaxed place to have something to eat late night.

As far as the yelp pictures helped me out in finding this place I gotta say that I was impressed from what a lady can do late night in a kitchen by herself. The waitress had sent out the banchan before my meal so I had the dried fish, fish cake and kimchi. The kimchi wasn't as spicy but I expect so from being a spicy dish. Either I became immune to spicy foods or its just me. 

 Seafood Paejun was great I had a big one that took up the whole plate, I also had the Seafood Dolsot Bibimbap. I was a bit puzzled at first cause she had an egg yolk placed in there and the lady told me to stir while it was still sizzling :D
At first I had a tea to warm me up from the outside cause it was very cold.. but I swapped up since I was gonna eat big again and have my fill so I ordered a bottle of hite to go with my meal. For every 5 mins the lady would ask me if I ws doing alright. I was taking my time since I finished my Dolsot faster than I had my Paejun. I had to take half of it home cause I was stuffed afterwards. It was really great that I had a nice dinner and experience from just a waitress and a lady. She was really nice with everything and gave me a smile before I left. I felt better after searching for this place to experience something new. :)
author: Xeirhen V.

description:
My family and I have been coming here for awhile now and we'll always order the same items because it's the best in SF.  

1) Mandu
2) Sam Gyeop Sal

Throw in a bottle of soju, a dish of garlic and we're in heaven!!  Other items that we love but are not always readily available Odeng Tang & Gol Beng

I usually never comment on a restaurants tea, but I could drink an entire pot myself.  The temperature is perfect not to hot or cold and I believe the owner mixes two or more flavors to give it its distinct flavor.
author: Stacey L.

description:
I came here one evening this past week and ordered a beef soybean paste soup. It was done on the spicy side and it was delicious. At $8.95, the price was very reasonable also. It came with six small side dishes.

The restaurant had very nice decor also. I give much credit to the way it appears to be a one-person operation at the time of my visit, and the lady was very nice.
author: H K.

description: I love this place! Every time I go here there's only one older lady running the whole place. So, much props to her. I've been here on both busy and slow nights and the service is always amazing. She has to be the sweetest server I've ever met! Always attends to everyone and returns to your table frequently to see how everything is. On a busy night I dont feel like the wait for food was long at all. She takes orders and cooks alone, from what I noticed, and she's pretty quick with everything. I love that this place is open late... You know when you have those late night cravings for KimChee fried rice. It used to be open until 2am but I guess hours have changed because it's usually dead around midnight. The only thing negative about this place is it seems a bit pricey. It never stopped me from going there though! Open late, great service, good food... why not ;)
author: Audrey W.

description:
I ate here a long time ago, and someone else was buying so let that be a caveat.
We went with a very large group and the staff was very accommodating. I recall several bottles of Sake and Soju being comped. We pretty much ordered everything on the menu and left completely satisfied. Having someone who speaks Korean was also probably to our advantage.
author: Nik K.

description:
2.5
Simple menu with a homestyle korean mom taste

Seafood pancake
too much doughy taste and there are less onions and seafood pieces than other seafood pancake at other korean places I have eaten at. Average at best.

Spicy squid with vegetables
small pieces of squid smothered in sauce, muchrooms, and onions. Decent but was not anything to rave about.

Kimchi beef rice with fried egg on top
small portions and quite unremarkable. 

Overall, small portions at average prices and taste. The owner/cook was visibly delighted to see us when we first walked in. There are other better korean restaurants in san francisco.
author: Robert Y.

description: This place is absolutely delicious! 5 stars because of the sweet and super friendly owner, and mouth-watering fabulous food. Great spot :)
author: Lauren B.

description:
I felt that everything was either bland or too salty.

I have never had fish cake (that came as a side dish) that was so soft (not a good thing). All the side dishes were quite bland.

I ordered seafood tofu soup. The broth was red. Other places are usually orange. They cracked the egg in the soup prior to serving us the dish which I disliked. Most places give me the egg and I can crack it in myself - which is what I prefer.

I ordered a silver noodle dish and it was super salty. I mixed it in with plain white rice and it was better.

Not coming again.
author: Amy T.

description:
Um Ma Son is a hidden gem in the outer Richmond.  Friendly service, nice and quiet atmosphere, and excellent Korean food for a reasonable price.

The four of us ordered four dishes, in addition to all the small apps given.  And yes, we asked for seconds because we are fatties.

Seafood pancake - the dipping sauce that it came with meshed with the dish perfectly.  I wish there were more, though. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/NcwP3kUy90oadOkRLcGO4w?select=8UbisNnBF03DLdqOhacDhA

Jap chae - I don't know why, but jap chae is my weak spot.  I never find many good ones, because they're usually too oily to the point where oil drips down your chin.  This one is no exception, but it was still mighty tasty.  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/NcwP3kUy90oadOkRLcGO4w?select=WO_QVVNJB8dUgSOHdyb73Q

Soft tofu soup with beef, extra spicy.  But, not spicy enough in my mind.  Got a nice heat to it, and goes great with your bowl of rice. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/NcwP3kUy90oadOkRLcGO4w?select=NpAS9tSRzZ7UZ4I8t21Snw

Spicy pork bulgogi - I'm not a big pork fan, but when it's cooked right, like this, I'll have a heaping plate! http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/NcwP3kUy90oadOkRLcGO4w?select=OW4DgE-Cs6jOX2AAkUjaqg

The restaurant was empty (besides our table) on a Friday night at 7:00.  Not sure why, maybe because the word hasn't gotten out yet?  Though I wouldn't want to wait in line like My Tofu House, either.  Is there no happy medium?
author: Jenny L.

description: Good Korean food at a good price. Quick service. Very intimate environment.  Try it out!!!
author: Alice C.

description:
If you love Korean food then this is the place  for you!!!! I came in here for the first time and was greeted by a very nice lady!! Turns out she was the only one there working!! She cooked and served for us and 3 other tables with 2 or more people,, it was great!!!!
I'm very impressed and highly recommend trying the sizzling rice bowls!!! I will be back!!!
author: Matt M.

description:
Awesome authentic Korean food!

Lived in Korea and this is the real thing, open late, super friendly staff, big menu and great flavorful fresh food! The woman who cooks all the food remembered what we ordered after not seeing us for months! Best Korean food in SF!
author: Lucas S.

description:
Mmm...seafood tofu soup on a cold (!!)  San Francisco summer(!!) evening.  Very comforting!  Us girls came here for dinner last night, and it's a cutely decorated place a little far out there on Geary but worth the venture.  Gotta love the vegetable side dishes (ask the lady to bring you more!) and steamy hot tofu soup!  I will definitely come back!

Seafood tofu soup+tax+tip = $9

Once-a-week dinner w/ Geraldine # 5
author: Maile N.

description:
The wife had a hankering for some Korean and as we were over this side of town after the bluegrass festival we did some research and came across this place. Our actual 1st choice said that the wait for 2 was 2-3 hours. It was a little longer than we wanted to so we searched again.

It's a cutesy little place with a warm feeling. Everything seems slow here. In a good way.

We had the seafood pancake to start and it was LARGE. It tasted excellent, the perfect dough and seafood mix. We had gotten through 75% and were full before our entrees arrived! lol

We got the kalbi and the dolsot bimbimbapboodobebop.
Great choices. The kalbi was succulent and flavored exactly the way it should be and if not for the price, we would have got some more!!

The BBB (for short) was piping hot as it should be and was very good as well. We finished everything so that's usually a good sign. And we were full.

I'm sure we will be back.
author: Nick L.

description: Worst customer service I've ever had at a Korean restaurant. We had a large (12people) crowd and the ONE SERVER/OWNER/COOK WAS SO RUDE AND IMPOLITE!! I am so livid!! She took away our food before we even finished gave us only 3 cups of water she was mad that we didn't order what she wanted us to order. She kept pushing for us to order more but we didn't know if we liked it so we turned her down. She slammed all her pots and pans when she cooked and served us and when we asked for rice she charged $3 for a tiny bowl!!! I've grown up with Korean food high and low end and the rice she gave us was definitely not worth $3. Our total came out to $160 for 3 dishes what the hell?! And might I add the food was old and was tasted like she kept it in the fridge and brought it out and microwaved it. The dok Bo ki was basically rice covered in ketchup. If I could give this 0 stars I would. If I were you I'd pass on this food-poisoned-hell-joint for mc Donald's. Don't be desperate.
author: Serena M.

description: The service was good but the food was dog doo. The dishes are not the same as the photos on yelp. Especially the spicy rice cake. The tofu soup was also made with salty sea water.
author: Steven C.

description:
I haven't been back in awhile because it's so far from me and it doesn't have the best parking. This spot used to be my go-to Korean spot, I'm all about delicious hae mul pa jeon and kalbi. The price is ok too. 

They have friendly, albeit at times slow, service. I'd still handily recommend this place, but I'd just as easily go to muguboka nearby in the same 'hood... A few stops closer to my side of town.
author: Erika C.

description:
I don't know how I went the whole day without eating but I did.
So by the time I got to Um Ma Son, my head was pounding, my stomach was growling, and I was twitching so much you would think I was being remotely prodded.
In short, I was a mess.

Not only did this place have to deliver good eats, but it had to do it before I keeled over.
But no pressure right?

I'm elated to say they came through in a big way.
Their homemade dumplings hit the spot.  It was pan fried and just a little greasy - it was the way I like it.
The bulgogi was cooked on the well side but that didn't stop me from scrafing it down.
The wife's bibimbap was made with great care and she said she could taste the love.

The service here was like our server: sweet.
She knew just the right time to check on us and must of known I was starving since the food started coming out as I was about to black out.  I liked her.

Overall, Um Ma Son is an awesome eatery.  It's small and inviting and fairly comfortable.  The food is warm and filling and they're also open late night - you know, for my midnight munchies.
author: Dan B.

description:
I was craving for Korean, and I found this place on Yelp. It seems to have really good review. 

It is indeed a very small place but it was cozy. The food was excellent. My friends and I had the BBQ Chicken, the Kalbi, the seafood pancake, and the dumpling soup. The seafood pancake was more than enough. It was very good and tasty. I love chicken so when the chicken came I was excited. The chicken was very well marinated with no MSG. The dumpling soup had a very nice broth. There was no hint of MSG in any of the dishes that we ordered. 

I recommend this place to those who enjoy food.  :). The owner was very fast in delivering food and checking up on the their customers.
author: Sadie P.

description:
3.5 stars

Came here tonight (saturday) around 6pm. It was quite empty and there was only 1 customer. I guess it was still early so there was no one. This place is very tiny and when we arrived there was only one old lady serving us. She was very friendly but sometimes we have hard time understanding each other =P She's basically the one who served and who cooked. 

My favorite of the night was dol sot bi bim bap. It's very delicious, however the portion was a bit small. Jap chae was too saucy and it tasted a bit different from what i used to have. As for bbq we ordered the Galbi and spicy pork. They were very tender and tasty. We had also ordered the chicken wings, which was on the salty side. Seafood pancake was so-so, I have had better.

Overall it's a nice experience. The only complaint is that the portion is pretty small for what they charged.
author: Louisa L.

description: Been here countless times. Friendly and comfortable place to eat late at night. I always order the Kim Chee Chi Gae and it's always good. Just how I like it. The other day, we tried the bulgogi and it was not as good as I thought it would be.
author: Sara S.

description:
Disclaimer: This is my first review on Yelp, so you know it must have been good for me to write in hopes of keeping this place going. I'm a foodie, so no worries about my tastebuds.

Came here on a weekday evening with a friend and was skeptical at first because the place was deserted. It was my first time here. We just wanted something quick and delicious and the nice lady behind the counter did not disappoint. She is a "one woman show" as other reviewers have said. She does basically everything! 

We ordered the small kimchee pancake (but it was huge!) and the special Bi Bim Bap in the clay pot with the crack-added (I mean crackling) rice at the bottom.  The pancake was not overly doughy, could have been slightly crispier, but very good all the same. The BBB was delicious with a runny fried egg on top! She mixed it all up for us and we feasted. The lady even came by later to help us scrape the last yummy, crispy bits of rice at the bottom for us! There was plenty of food for two. I don't know what people are complaining about the small portions.

 I've overlooked this place so many times and I live just a few blocks away. I know where I'm going the next time I'm craving Korean food and don't feel like smelling like smoke after leaving Brother's. Can't wait to try the Bul go gi! Um Ma Son, I will definitely be coming back :)  A Mother's Hand gets a high five from me.
author: Lila C.

description:
My first review of 2011! Seems like my general laziness has seeped into my Yelp life as well, since I've been resorting to obsessively checking in everywhere on my Yelp app (who checks in at U-Haul? Answer: Jen L. does.) to try to dominate the Yelposphere rather than writing helpful reviews for my adoring fans. I'm only now getting around to writing reviews again, specifically this one, out of sheer guilt.

I came here for dinner with E about a week and a half ago and ever since I started eating healthy foods (veggie and whole grains) to avoid scathing remarks from my relatives regarding my weight ("You've gotten so round!") when I travel to China this summer, I've been a little...out of it (i.e., bumping into walls and muttering curses at romaine lettuce). Unfortunately, in my salad-induced haze, I somehow suppressed my innate Asian mathematical aptitude and calculated tip incorrectly, giving the sweet woman who works here less than 15% tip.

E pointed this out later that night and I vowed to write a review for Um Ma Son to try to compensate for my accidental stinginess. (That said, I won't let my overwhelming guilt bias my review or taint my Yelp integrity!) I'll admit that we had originally set out to dine at Han Il Kwan, my favorite Korean joint in the city, but when we drove by, we saw that Han Il Kwan was undergoing some construction so we decided to try out Um Ma Son since it was closeby and seemed to get rave reviews on Yelp.

When we arrived, we were greeted by a cute little Korean woman. She apparently does all the cooking and waitressing herself (OH THE GUILT!), but we didn't have any issues with waiting too long for our food and she was still very attentive, checking up on us several times and cooing over E and his love for Korean food.

We got the seafood pancake, kimchi fried rice, and yuk gae jang (spicy beef stew), and everything was yummy. I would definitely say that I prefer the kimchi fried rice at Toyose, since the one here was a bit too oily, which diluted the kimchi taste. I loved the side dishes here though, they were definitely simple but very flavorful and home-y. 

I'd definitely come back when I'm in the mood for homestyle Korean cooking. I love Han Il Kwan, but it definitely has a restaurant vibe and taste (if that even makes sense at all...is this the salad talking again?). Um Ma Son (which roughly translated means "Mother's Hand") feels more like a private dining room and it tastes more like the food I used to have at home. Comforting, delicious, and guilt-ridden.
author: Jen L.

description:
So so so so good.

I love the bi bim bap, the chicken wings (only available sometimes!) and the beef and pork.  The kimchi is delicious.  And I love the spotty service - on most nights, the owner alone is hostess / waitress / chef.  And she does great!

Not cheap, but worth the price.  Not alway open late, though.  We tried to go at 11 last week and she was already closed for the night.
author: Melanie K.

description:
i never saw this restaurant until I drove past it while going to get my nails done the other day and knew I had to come here. Restaurant itself was small but cute.. It needs a bit of art work or something on the wall though, too plain.. We were greeted by the owner lady and she was super cute and sweet...

I walked in here knowing what I wanted since I love trying Kalbi when I eat Koren food. Their menu is pretty small compared to the bigger Korean restaurants but as long as they have what I want, I'm happy... 

I wanted to try the seafood pancake but knew I wouldn't finish it so I just ordered the Kalbi ($18.95) and the BF ordered the Kim Chee Bok Um Bap(Kim chee fried rice with beef and egg $9.95). The little dishes given wasn't as much as I though it would be but it was good and when the Kalbi came, I scarfed that yummy thing down as if I haven't eaten in days/weeks.. Plenty of meat but not enough for how much you pay for. The meat itself was tender and flavorful but it's just too expensive... The kim chee fried rice was another story. It tasted so weird I couldn't even take two bites. The beef didn't even exist... If you try this and think you can handle SPICY, make sure you have lots of ice water because it is REALLY spicy....

Next time maybe I'll give the Bi Bim Bap($9.95) a try since it looks really good when I was taring at the other patrons eating it!

OPEN TIL 2 IN THE MORNING!
author: Juliane N.

description: I'm eating in Um ma son right now~ and it's so~~delicious!! Also owner woman is so kind :) i will come here often!!!
author: Laura S.

description:
I normally don't complain about food.
I never leave the table unless i'm full. (especially when i paid for it)

BUT...
I complained the whole time i was here.
I didn't finish my food, and i left hungry. I'd rather starve than eat...

I had Gam Ja tang "potato stew?"... which was flavorless.
I won't be coming back here. NEVER again.
author: Sora B.

description:
Really good bibimbap! I especially like the rice crispy at the bottom!
My bf ordered the tofu stew and we liked the spiciness of it. Services was excellent and fast even though the lady did everything by herself.

When we were eating, the health inspector came to the restaurant to do the annual health inspection and they got 100 again! The lady proudly show us the green inspection paper and we said congratulations to her!lol

Will be back for sure. Good food and good price. Slight cheaper than normal Korean restaurants : D
author: Ris L.

description:
After living down the street for two and a half years, how did I not notice this place?

I haven't had Korean food in a long time, and this one did the job.  The owner, whom I'm assuming was the owner was very nice and attentive. The place is open late and the food is good, but not great.  A little pricey I feel, but nevertheless, the kind of place you want to patronize because you know the owners work hard and most of all, are nice to you.
author: Grape C.

description:
Here's what I like about the place:
-Open late night
-Friendly staff
-Quick service 
-Good food 
-Staff refilled our side dishes =)
-Flavorful tofu soup...yum

Here's what was okay about the place:
-It doesn't look like the most cleanest restaurant - then again, these hole in the wall places may not look nice, but they have good food
author: Michelle F.

description: Came here around 11pm on a Thursday night and the lady who owns the shop was awesome. Best seafood pancake I've had at a Korean restaurant! The Japchae was a little more oily than I would have liked, but still really yummy. Hubby got kimchi jjigae and said it was really good. We also got the pork mandu, which was ok but not stellar. Hubby liked to put them into his kimchi jjigae :). The lady was all by herself and was the waiter and cook at the same time. She was amazing! Service was very good! She accidentally made an order of ddeokbokki for a table while we were there and she gave it to them on the house. To our luck, they decided to share it with us! Would come back for a late night korean food craving that isn't kbbq.
author: Jhermaine D.

description:
My boyfriend was craving some Hawaiian Bbq but there weren't any worthwhile to be found. So, I searched for Korean food instead and found this place. Reviews were pretty accurate.

We ordered take-out around 5pm on a Friday night. Small place, not much decor, and not crowded at all. There was a couple dining when we walked in and a lady came shortly after. I guess that's why there were only 2 people working that night.. There was good service, and we didn't wait long. The server even brought us some tea to drink while we waited.

We only ordered 3 items and were surprised to get 2 orders of rice and delicious condiments in addition. I don't remember what exactly it was we ordered, but it was their most popular seafood pancake, short ribs, and spicy noodles with tofu. Everything was complimentary together, the spices were perfect(although a bit more spice would be nice), and filled us up nicely. Just what we were looking for.

My only complaint would be that it was a bit pricey, although we did get plenty of food. For those 3 items, it came out to about $46. But it was delicious regardless!
author: Alexandra T.

description: Good dolsot bibimbap with tasty veggies and beef over perfectly cooked rice. Not much variety with the banchan, and overall a little salty. Friendly service. Place could've used some cool air. I'd have to try a few more dishes before making up my mind about this place.
author: Sophia B.

description:
Called them a little after midnight to see if they were still open. Yes! They were open! We went the night before and they were closed. :(

Got there about 5 minutes later. The place was empty. There was an Asian lady behind the register and a Hispanic male sitting on the corner booth. The lady smiled and asked if we were the ones who called then quickly seated us.

We quickly browsed through the menu and placed our orders:
- Beef Bulgogi
- Jap Chae
- Soon Dobu 

The food came out fairly fast. The rice was barely warm. I would prefer it a little bit warmer. The side dishes (i.e. kim chi, bean sprout, cucumbers, tofu skin, anchovies, and daikon radish) were okay. The kim chi wasn't very spicy. The bean sprout was really salty. Cucumbers had too much sesame oil. Tofu skin has a bit too much anchovy paste. Daikon radish tasted a little funny; maybe it was just a not-so-great radish. Beef bulgogi was very tender. A tad too sweet for my taste. Jap Chae was really sweet and kind of watery; good flavor though, maybe just had one too many tablespoons of sauce. Soon Dofu was good. I would like a bit more broth. A little bit too salty; good with rice. ;)

Service was great. The lady was very friendly and attentive. She came over to scoop our soup for us. Made me feel like I was at home being pampered/spoiled by mom. She noticed my boyfriend ran out of rice and asked if he'd like a second. We were the only customers (surprisingly), but she never rushed us and were super duper nice to us. I really wanted to give her a hug before we leave, but I was too stuffed.

The environment was nice and comfy. The place was clean. The lighting was more kind of dim, which I like better than Asian places with bright fluorescent lights. The decor was simple.
author: Jennifer L.

description: I love this place! When it's late, there's only one woman who cooks and waits tables, but she's incredibly friendly and goes as quick as she possibly can. The food is super affordable and delicious. I always get the Kimchi Pancake or Kimchee Jun on their menu ($9.95) and the Dol Sot Bi Bim Bab ($11.95). The kimchi pancakes has an amazing crunchy texture on the outside and soft inside, and is extremely affordable compared to the other Korean restaurants around the Richmond district. The Bi Bim Bap is in a stone pot and is my favorite meal to get at a Korean restaurant. Again, the Bi Bim Bap is really adorable as it normally goes for around $15-$17 elsewhere. The sides that are normally served at any Korean restaurant are delicious and she even refills any one you'd like! Warning though, the soups (like Soon Du Bu) don't come with rice so make sure to order one on the side if you prefer to eat it that way!
author: Jamey M.

description:
the little lady is sooo cute. she really made me feel at home. 

we got the:

kalbi- pretty good. not as charred as I like it
potstickers- boiled, tasted much healthier than the fried versions
tofu kimchi soup- really good, just wish there was a little more broth and meat
seafood pancake- pretty tasty. definitely one of the better ones I've had
mango soju- really sweat but pretty tasty nonetheless
yogurt soju- sooooo good

Dont get why they don't get more traffic, the food is so good! I'll definitely be back. :)
author: Lisa N.

description: Post outside lands an open beacon beckoned in the richmond. Maybe 30 bench seats with rush mats upon. Ordered the favs, fried chicken wings, be bim bap, dumplings and seafood pancakes. Banchan of course, 2 giant beers, $74 all in. Loved it all, seafood pancake in particular loaded with octopus and shellfish variety. Dumplings were delicate and tasted of green herbs and porky lusciousness. Sf is such an early closing town, do yourself a favor when you're out late and pop in here. Asian kids know the score, they were packing the place after we left at 11, open till 2 and the owners are happy you're there. Friendly and anxious to please.
author: Kelly K.

description: It was just ok for me. The kim chi and seafood pancake was really good. The kim chi fried rice and bi bim bop was ok. Tofu soup was ok. Jap chae was really good. The 2 dishes that I didn't really like were the spicy pork which just didn't really taste that fresh and the bulgogi (the meat was large pieces and kind of tough).
author: Mai H.

description:
Came here for dinner tonight since we wanted to try some place new since we always go to Tofu House.

Got inside and it wasn't busy and it was pretty small. At least we didn't have to wait or anything. Ordered our food and asked the waiter if it was enough for 9 people, he said it was. The side dishes wasn't that memorable, and they give you really little to start with too. I guess I'm used to having a variety of side dishes.

The tofu soups came out and it was flavorful all flavorful. Then the kal bi came, and I was a bit disappointed since there was literally only one piece per person. Usually at tofu house they give you a lot, but over here my eyes just kind of blinked. We also ordered some kind of cod fish dish, but that wasn't very good at all. The sauce was good, but the fish itself was dry, and rubbery. Definitely will stay away from that dish. Then we realized either the waiter didn't understand us, or he just eats really little, but that wasn't enough food! So we added a bibimbop, bugolgi, and a seafood pancake. All were very good, but again smaller portions than usual. The seafood pancake though was really good, fresh seafood, and it was just yummy all around.

Overall the food was good, minus the cod fish. It's a little pricey compared to other Korean restaurants since they give you a smaller portion. I would come here for the seafood pancake, but otherwise I'm still a big fan of tofu house.
author: Johnson S.

description:
I love this place. It truly felt like I was at my Korean (i'm not Korean) mom's restaurant. 

Seriously. She totally guided me through what I should order and how i should eat it. It must have been a slow night for me and my friend Gary M. because I swear, not only did she take our order (and made recommendations) she was back there making it! You really can't get any more authentic than that. 

 I totally felt like I disappointed her when I over-sauced my bim-bim-bap. But she smiled and threw up her hands. Totally un-Amy Chua. So awesome. 

Seriously guys,check it out. Great experience.
author: Roth E.

description: "Um Ma Son" Translates to mothers hand. This restaurant lives up to that name. The owner takes your order, cooks it, and then serves it to you. Soft tofu soup is amazing, start with the Kimchi pancake!!
author: Jason L.

description: I feel bad giving a bad review to a family owned small Korean restaurant however the food were not really edible they used cheap ingredients and use a lot of MSG or packaged instant stuff....worst Korean food ever...  never  again.
author: Sam A.

description: The dol sot bi bim bap was going on!!! The ban chan was fresh and tasty. Staff was friendly.
author: Johnny C.

description:
I was craving some Korean food and decided to try somewhere new. It was kind of late at night so only one person was working and it was this older Korean woman, I felt kind of bad that she was the only one there!

1. Ddukboki: Right when I ordered it she told me that they dont use the long rice cakes that you usually use for ddukboki and I said it's okay. The sauce is a bit bland and she said it's because they tried to make it less spicy for non-Koreans. I've definitely had better elsewhere so I don't think I'll be getting this again here...

2. Dwin jang chi gae: I was craving this and it was definitely worth it! Tasted great, probably uses more red pepper paste than the bean paste (I can taste it and because of the spiciness) I recommend this for people who crave this soup or have never tried it. If you're the type to always get soondubu, you should try this.

3. My friend ordered the dduk mandu gook: It was surprisingly good! I think because the soup was kind of a beef stock base with a lot of pepper (might want to tell them to not put any salt and pepper so you can just do it yourself). 

It was all really good, highly recommend this place for someone who is looking for a decent Korean restaurant. If you're Korean, the lady is super sweet because she asks if everything tastes okay and such in Korean --- not saying that if you're not Korean she's mean or anything haha.

Enjoy!
author: Seung L.

description:
Um Ma Son, you're lucky you have great tasting food, otherwise my 3-star review would have been a 2. Why do so many people give it 4 or 5 stars? I'm confused.

The service was lacking the night my brother and I went. We were seated immediately, but the people who walked in behind us were served their kimchi apps and even a dish before we got our apps or waited on. It was probably around twenty minutes before we got anything served to us. I had to ask the girl working if we could get service! A large party that walked in after us walked up to their fridge to help themselves to beer and soda. Great that people feel right at home to help themselves, but where's the courtesy? Maybe they were short staffed, as I only saw two people working that night, and both were doing the cooking as well.

We ordered
seafood pancake - hearty and very generous with the seafood, everyone else isn't lying, it's good
chicken bbq- seasoned to perfection
tofu soondubu- spiiiiiicy, but niiiiiice

Not sure if I'd go back.. Would probably peek in to see if they're not short staffed, fortunately enough I had just watched the King's speech, so I wasn't cranky despite the cruddy service.
author: Geralyn Y.

description:
I just moved back out to the Richmond district, and this place has a fan for life.

I'd finished a grueling moving day, and it was 11:30pm. OMG! The Richmond district has shut down!

Yelp says differently! Oh, and I FREAKING LOVE KOREAN FOOD!

The woman who runs this place is super-nice, and even tried to teach me some more Korean (I only know hello, thank you, "side dishes," and goodbye). Awesomeness!

While out of the Kalbi, I tried the soft tofu soup with beef, and it was delightful. Love that soft tofu, and just enough meat to flavor the soup itself.

If craving Korean food past 10pm (even on a Sunday night! yes!!), I know where I'll be.
author: Cody K.

description:
Having lived in Korea long enough to sample a good variety of the food there, I can say that this place lives up to it's name:  "A Mother's Hand." This mother deserves five stars for being host, waitress, cook, manager and owner in one person.  She puts love into her work.  On one weekend night she had closed late and was walking on Geary when my friend and I were walking the other way after the bar we were in closed.   "Want to eat?" she asked and invited us back to the restaurant, which she opened up again, just for us.  The seafood pancakes are outstanding.
Bibimbap and soft tofu soup rate high too.   Bring your friends!
author: Philip R.

description: One of my favourite restaurants and is the most memorial; I had my first and real Korean food from this restaurant since August 2009. I wasn't into Korean food at all for my first few times eating there until half a year later, I fell in love with their kimchi bokum; very original and unique. I haven't eaten there since I moved to the East Bay last summer and definitely missed it. I would like to give it 4.5 star instead of 5 because its price is not the most reasonable but it is not a problem to round it up to 5!
author: Victor C.

description:
Very unassuming place. But don't be fooled, as the food is good and the lady who seemingly runs every aspect alone is rad.

Short ribs? Simple and tasty. Seafood pancake? Yum. Had to wait a while to get our check but as I said above, one lady seemed to be running the show.

Not exactly a date spot but the food was quality and the price was right.
author: Nate R.

description:
This place is the best kept secret for Korean food in SF!  I honestly don't know why this place isn't packed every night because this place has it all.  The banchan is so much better than anywhere else in the city and my Kalbi Tang was actually edible and delicious, unlike some of the other places in SF.

What really makes this place special is the old lady that runs the whole restaurant.  She always has a smile on her face and really goes the extra mile to make sure that her customers are happy.

Go before this place becomes the new hot spot for Korean!
author: Theo T.

description:
Finally got to try this place a few weeks ago and loved it!!

Open late...came here around 11:30PM and stayed almost till closing (drinking that soju).  Nice small, cute place deep in the Richmond.  

- Kalbi...cooked to perfection
- seafood pancake...really good...but way too big
- beef tofu soup...loved it.
