This place is a plus just because it is open late.
author: Patrick C.

description: The food here is delish ! I loved their tofu soup and their spicy pork ! The kim-chee fried rice here is meh, it was a bit too greasy and buttery for my liking. The restaurant is really cute and small. The pricing is your typical korean food in SF pricing. The downside about this restaurant is that when it gets hectic you will not get what you ask for from the servers. The service can get very slow and annoying because there's only one person serving and one person cooking. There are a lot of people that order take-outs too , so your food might take awhile to come. Also parking is awful on geary =[. Amidst all of the bad stuff I would still come back.
author: Lucy C.

description:
Very, very good.  

Mandoo soup - Delicious!!!  Some of the best mandoo ive ever had.  Soup was very well flavored, very tasty, not overly salty or oily.

Kim Chee Fried Rice - Very Good, very interesting.  Unlike any kim chee fried rice ive had before.  My girlfriend said it was too oily tasting.  I disagree.  

Side dishes - Excellent.  The bean sprouts were extremely good, while all the other ones were great too.  Some of the best bean sprouts ive ever had.  

And the best part - supposedly no MSG.  It tasted so damn good its hard to believe...but yeah, no MSG, and the food was GREAT!  Will definitely be coming back to try the other menu items.
author: Sage S.

description:
I was hoping to find a back up to my fave Richmond K joint, Han Il Kwan, but Um Ma Son comes up short.

I really, really, really, want to support the place as it's a small local biz, but they need some help to differentiate themselves from other Korean restaurants.

My meh dining experience started when I tried to order yuk gae jang because I wanted a simple, hearty, spicy soup to chase off yet another cold and miserable rainy night in SF. But alas, DENIED. I think that was the first time ever that I went to a K joint and was told they couldn't make yu gae jang, which almost sounds like they don't get enough orders for the dish to keep ingredients around.

After this denial, I began to wonder if the restaurant had enough traffic to sustain itself for the long haul, as the place was nearly empty at around 8:30 in the evening.

Maybe I can also sense the air of desperation in the place, considering they currently have a half-off happy hour liquor deal after 10PM. Yes, boys and girls, happy hour AFTER 10PM.

So I ordered the following instead for me and my dining companion:

- Kimchi Bok Um Bap

Simple prep of kimchi fried rice made with kimchi stir fried with rice with grilled egg on top. It was good and decent, but not much better than what I can whip up at home on my own.

- Kimchi chee gae

It was piping hot and spicy, filled chock full of kimchi and pork, but the broth lacked the depth of flavor I find at places like Shin Toe Bul Yi and Han Il Kwan. I think the portion size was slightly smaller as well.

- Fried chicken (not on menu, picture on wall)

Not as good as the KFC at Shin Toe Bul Yi, but it was pleasant enough fried chiken. Not too spicy (surprising), and served with something that tasted like a mixture of Thai/Vienamese chili sauce and kochujang.

There were 7 banchan selections served with our meal. Pretty standard fare stuff like cucumber, water radish, bean sprout, kimchi, anchovy, and fish cake. The curveball was the pickled deulkkae leaves which would have gone well with meat, which we didn't order. I was disappointed that they didn't serve ggak du gi.

There were more options on the menu, including $20+ jungol type dishes, but we took a pass on them on this visit as we were in the mood for a simple dinner that was light on meat.

The dining room is small and intimate, so it could be a really cozy place for a good meal. And with umma's (presumably the proprietor) gracious and attentive service (not creepy at all you haters), it could be a really awesome experience.

Unfortunately, there are much better options.

I think Um Ma Son can do much better if they can improve on the formula at Toyose in outer Sunset. If a place like that can thrive in a converted garage for chrissakes, Um Ma Son can do better by tweaking their menu and serve more dishes like they have in Korean hofs or even street food and courting a hipster clientele with kiddie soju drinks.
author: Bono B.

description:
Lonely.  Inconsistent.  Amateur.

As the name of this restaurant translate's to "Mom's Hand," and with the traditional stews and dishes hard to find elsewhere in Frisco, I hate to short Um Ma Son 2 stars.  The food however, is extremely hit or miss, and the barren restaurant on Saturday night "dinner rush" hours belies the high star ratings from my fellow yelpers.

Service: Being the only table from 7-8:30 on Saturday, the service from the ah-ju-mah (elderly lady) became borderline obtrusive and slightly awkward.  While service checks and smiles are key to successful customer service, asking if everything is okay after every 3 bites proves difficult to hold conversation with your company.

Food:  
*The CODFISH STEW is delicious.  Boiled till bubbling right on your table, the stew refreshes and comforts by way of the asian radish and meaty cod harmony.  A perfect remedy for the cold inner Richmond summer evenings.  Careful of bones though!

*Jap Chae - Well known to any Korean food fanatic, this common noodle appetizer was drowning in soy sauce and oil, lacked necessary vegetables, and had one too many unwarranted shakes of black pepper.  Major miss.

*Kim chi Pancake - Crisp on the outside and hot on the inside (good). Kimchi flavors lacking and slightly awry.  Something to eat if you're bored.  (Hit/miss)

*Ban Chan (side dishes) - Miss. Miss. Miss. Kimchi - def not made by MY mama's hands.  I pity the fool...

*Soft Tofu Soup - Tastes like: water, red chili pepper flakes, soft tofu.  No soothing complexities.  Stops boiling in clay pot way too soon.  Miss.

Ambiance:  On one hand, there's something royal about being the only guest in a small restaurant for your entire meal with full attention from your server.  On the other hand, it's very weird/creepy.

Will definitely be go back on a depressing day for the Cod Fish stew, otherwise, it's bust.

$9-20 ave. per dish.  Slightly intrigued by the meat dishes....
author: Jane L.

description:
great place for Korean that's just a couple of blocks away from my apt!! 

I've yelped this place and was curious about the 'super woman' who apparently does it all, so came here on two separately occasions with a couple of friends for some late-night K-grub. 

Yes, this place is almost always empty but you're immediately welcomed in by the woman owner upon entrance. She's very warm and attentive. The food is yummy (i've had the soondooboo, steamed and fried mandu, bibimbap, and fresh-tasting banchan). 

Again let me reiterate the amazing woman who owns this place! she really tends to you at your meals as if you're having dinner over at mama's house! She came by a couple of times to ask if the dishes taste okay, and if we needed anything else. When my friends were having soju she asked if we were driving and seemed very genuine about making sure we were happy there. 

Kudos to - yes - the super woman, and to her delicious homemade-tasting meals!!
author: Jing D.

description: This is becoming my regular go to for Korean food. I love Korean food and I love it spicy. This is a great mom and pop run by an older lady who does all the cooking and serving. I've never had to wait. Parking isn't hard. The customer service is great. They gave my dad a free beer for father's day and brought the food to my car when I ordered take out. IRS comparable in price to other Korean places. I really enjoy it and love the food.
author: Annie P.

description: Decent food but poor service. We didn't get our banchan until we asked for it 20 minutes after ordering, and then it arrived after the rest of our food. Big no-no for a Korean restaurant. Our waitress was rather awkward and frequently disappeared to the back for long periods of time.
author: Rob C.

description: Taste like home cooking, but the $20 bbq beef didn't meet my expectation of good Korean eats.
author: E T.

description: Had a delicious big clay pot of bibimbab to myself one night while out with my buddies. I'm actually a big fan of the cold bibimbab but the lady pushed me to get the hot clay pot one because she says it's better. I listened to her and wasn't disappointed, another guy ordered the sizzling bibimbab before me and he was chowing down on it like no other. Tons of different veggies with marinated beef and a sizzling sunny-side up  egg on top. Reasonably priced as well (I think around $11-12).
author: K. N.

description:
So unfortunately awful... from the banchan (side dishes) to the entrees. I left hungry and mad. :(

We ordered two dishes - the ddeok gook (rice cake soup) and dak gui (grilled chicken). The ddeok in the ddeok good was overcooked and mushy, and the soup broth was below average. The chicken tasted like it had been soaking in way too much soy sauce.

Maybe they had an off day b/c I don't know how else to explain the 4 star reviews? But I won't be back, and I suggest you take your appetite and wallet elsewhere.
author: Cheri S.

description:
Amazing.  

Food: great
Service: great

Also, sometimes the owner is a or (wo)man show.  It's amazing.  She zips around as the waitress, cook, cashier, hostess, dishwasher, etc.  It's quite impressive.  Get the special gal bi jim, you won't regret it!
author: Tony N.

description: This lady deserves 6 stars! I just LOVE her. She always makes absolutely delicious food! I feel like I am visiting my friend's grandmother whenever I eat here. Love that this place is open till 2 am. Seriously delicious, spicy food!! Makes my palate and tummy happy!!!!
author: Irina S.

description:
Whenever I'm looking for a new Korean or Chinese joint, I always check out Jason G's reviews.  He has been around around the block and then some when it comes to Asian food.

2 dol sot bi bim bap
Chap Jae 
Spicy tofu soup
Korean seafood pancake
Short rib soup

I used to date a Korean guy and his mom made the best spicy tofu soup and chap jae.  Um ma son's version was right up there!  The beef soup was simple with a clean taste, and tons of meet to eat with rice.  Hands down the best seafood pancake my lips have ever touched.  This is my new fave Korean resto in SF.

Prepare to be greeted by the sweetest Korean lady who will happily seat you, serve tea, and patiently waited for the rest of your party to park.  She's a one stop shop:  host, waitress, and cook.  Done with ease, no stress, and with a pleasant smile and disposition.  Don't be surprised if she scurries to the kitchen window and places your appetizer order asap before writing down the rest of your dishes.  Worked out nice because the hot steamy pancake came out within minutes!  

You'll notice the nice decor.  It's not your typical tofu house or korean bbq.  Ambiance is suitable for a date, but that night we felt like guests in her home.
author: Jennifer H.

description: my friends and i settled on this restaurant after two other unsuccessful attempts to eat at a korean place. service is pretty slow because there is only one waitress (luckily they didn't have a full house), but the food was pretty good. we got tofu soup, which is pretty hard to mess up, and japchae, a pretty big order of noodles, meat and veggies. yum! i wouldn't mind coming back again.
author: Sabrina L.

description:
Based on the reviews, I expected a cute, little "um-ma" to go scurrying about the kitchen preparing our food. While she was certainly cute & little - and she did scurry about to serve us - I was a bit disappointed that it looked like "oh-pa" prepared our food instead. Nevertheless, both soups certainly came out tasting like they were made by mother herself so I didn't mind!  

Yukgaejang (ordered extra spicy) had a beefy, deliciously red, deep taste. The onions and clear noodle complimented the super-soft, hand-shredded beef. One sip and I was in yukgaejang heaven! This was probably the best yukgaejang I've tasted in SF so far....

Kalbi-tang came out super-hot and had so much meat that hubby's eyes glazed over in delight. Unfortunately he was so greedy that by the time he offered to let me try some, it was only an empty bowl left with a few shards of bone (when it came out, there were several generous chunks of kalbi). The fact that he practically licked every last drop of broth and gnawed on the kabli bones probably meant it tasted really good. 

Um-ma watched intently as we drank our first sips of the soup to make sure we liked it, and making sure that we didn't need more rice or banchan. Not the fanciest place but oh-so homemade. At about $10 a dish, definitely worth coming back for!  Now if only I can find some way for her to adopt me so I'll have food like this every day.....

*Food = 4.25 stars but service is excellent + I like mom & pop places like this + it's the best yukgaejang I've tasted in SF so far = 5 stars
author: Colleen L.

description:
So we stopped in here super late night after the Outside Lands Festival. We had the Korean Tofu and it hit the spot perfectly. However, maybe because it was late - but I think the rice that was served was either re-heated or just not fresh. Also, there weren't as many of the small starters as I have seen at other korean restaurants. 
Still, there seemed to be only one woman working there that late so props to her for getting everything to us fast and tasty. Would definitely visit again if I were in the area.
author: Star M.

description:
Y "Um Ma Son" 

Yelp has done a great thing by providing me a quick directory to my latest food whim and cravings. 

As with everything, there is a dark side. 

In 2008, I celebrated my honeymoon with Yelp ,gained more than a couple of pounds, and tasted new cuisines. - is that right, cuisines?. What a jolly year! 

Back to the dark side, given I tried many new places, I'm finding that I'm not as easy to please. I take a closer look at the whole experience: service, location, selection and finally food. 

Given I'm not the type to complain about a restaurant unless I think it may help others and above mentioned, I haven't written. Until Now. 


Y "Um Ma Son" 
So good 

Food - YES! Bi Bim Bap -yum & gyozas yum yum! 
Service - Waitress/Owner? Rocked!! Very hospitable, home cooking, felt like I was a guest. 
Selection - good - had soups and BBQ as well 
Location - parking may be a challenge 

Back on track!
author: Stella B.

description:
Dol sot bibimbap 
chap chae 
spicy tofu soup 

I heard from Tony H and Brian P that this place was gangsta and this lady is an amazing woman.................they were right!!!! They were playing Korean hip hop and this lady was just off the hook. 

I came here with my girl Sara D and Ben L..................a threesome in all the wrong ways. Why can't Sara bring another girl???? 

She, the owner, is the host, the waitress, and the cook. She does it all................and that is the only reason why i am giving her 5 stars. If you work this hard..........you deserve it. In addition, she does it with a smile. Not the kind of smile you get from McDonald's..........but the kind of smile you get from a woman that honestly cares about her business and more importantly about you. 

This is a small restaurant. It can seat a maximum of 24 ppl. The price is very competitive and the food is very comparable to that of any Korean restaurants in the Richmond District. Um Ma Son................you complete me!!!!

Ya mah say oh!!!!
author: jason g.

description:
I would give this place a four and a half, but a four will have to do.

I came to SF to visit my friend. He never cooks for himself and eats out all the time ('spensive!).

We took a late nap and slept through dinner. By the time we thought to eat dinner, it was already past 9:30PM. Now, in Santa Cruz, or another places, the only options open would be diners. This is what I love about city life, like LA, there's always a plethora of options for food late at night.

We wanted to go some place close, and he seriously lives about 2-3 blocks away. AND this place is open until 2AM! 

We missed the place and had to turn around to find it. The lights that illuminate the sign were off, so it wasn't very noticeable. Luckily we got a spot right out front (parking is another thing that keeps me from coming out to SF very often).

Upon entering, the place was small (probably seats 50ish), but pretty full for a late night dinner. The vibe of the place was nice and was very clean. We were seated promptly by the "um-ma." Seeing all the different foods people were ordering looked delicious.

The prices on the menu are kind of up there, but then it looked as though the portions were enough for two, so then it's not so bad. He ordered the dol sot bibimbap. I had the ya chae soondubu.

It amazed me that there were only two people working, "um-ma" and the "ap-pa" (as Colleen L. called him). Hardcore seeing that they stay up that late Tuesday through Saturday just to serve people food. Really awesome and fortunate for the late night eaters.

The food was definitely yummy. My friend enjoyed his food (though he didn't care much for my beloved beansprout ends). I liked my soondubu. I didn't realize that there was mushrooms in it, which strongly flavored the soup, but I picked them all out, which actually significantly reduced the mushroom flavor. But even with the mushroom flavor, it was a delicious, savory stew. The egg was even cracked in for me, something I typically make a mess of my hands doing!

I am very pleasantly full from the yummy food here. I'll be sad when my friend moves to a different area (since he's just subletting) and we won't be close to Um Ma Son anymore.
author: Zi C.

description: Kimchii and seafood pancakes are DA BOMB: flavorful and pan-fried to perfection! I don't normally like Kimchii, but this just might be the gateway-food to regular Kimchii injest. I'd say avoid the BBQ chicken as it's pretty plain and Americanized.
author: Robin H.

description: Food was fine, not great and not bad.  The owner(s) very friendly, but had a hard time catering to 2 large parties.  We had a birthday party of 14 and the other group was 12.  The one lady cook had her handful trying to keep up with both parties.
author: Kmaintl L.

description:
this is a nice authentic korean place that i go once in a while.

i always try their kimchi pancake and galbi (beef rib eye stew) and they are fantastic.. they are very tender and perfectly marinated. we also tried their kimchi tofu and pork dish and they were perfectly executed in the way that i wanted it to be!

this is definitely one of better korean places.. especially for a small-mid sized and casual setting. their galbi is so good!
author: Sung C.

description:
This is 5 stars for the lady that runs the place till 2 a.m. This lady is freaking gangster! Let me tell you how gangster she is.  She's the hostess, the waitress, the cook, the cashier, and the dish washer! She's a one stop shop. Although she does all these things, she knows how to provide great service, and cook great food. I might not know what good Korean food is, but i do know that the Korean restaurants in San Francisco aren't that great. LA KOREAN RESTAURANTS ALL THE WAY!, but i think this place can compare to LA, unlike the other restaurants in SF. The lady can cook up some mean Kal Bi and Jap Chae! 

Come support this restaurant! Come support this gangster ass lady! I'll definitely be back!
author: Brian P.

description:
Came here for the first time for "new restaurant Friday" last night so it was something I was looking forward to all week. Let's just say I love Korean food and I definitely wasn't disappointed!

We arrived around 7pm and it was pretty empty...it's a small and cozy place with a welcoming ambiance. The overall service was great since the food came out quick (also piping hot!) and the waitress was very attentive to us...asking how we were doing and refilling our tea. There were 4 of us so we decided on 4 dishes:

Korean seafood pancake - This is one of my favorite dishes and I ALWAYS get it at Korean restaurants. It was made with pieces of squid, green onion, egg batter, and comes with a dipping sauce. I thought the ratio of the ingredients was perfect and wasn't too greasy. I probably ate most of the pancake...oops!

spicy soft tofu soup with beef - The soup came out still boiling in the bowl and it was perfectly spicy/flavored. The tofu was really silky, just the way I like it and there was a decent amount of ground beef in there. I kept coming back for more to put on my rice....mmm!

jap chae - This dish seemed a little too oily for some reason but was still super tasty. It's just like typical jap chae with clear rice noodles, shredded cabbage and carrots, mushrooms, and green onions.

dae gee bulgogi - This was the spicy pork one and it was delicious! Steaming hot and not too spicy on a bed of grilled onions...great to eat with rice. *drool* I kept eating it after I thought I was already full. =P

We ended with no leftovers because we were starving and the food was just too damn good but the portions were reasonable. I think we ate within 30 min too. haha It was perfect...also $15 a person for all that yummy food? Hell yes! I will be back!
author: Karen Y.

description:
I really want to give Um Ma Son more stars, but I'm not sure if the food was up to my standards. It's either a) my taste buds are now dulled to spicy foods, therefore I cannot really taste spicy foods anymore because I have become accustomed to them; or b) the food at Um Ma Son wasn't spicy at all and lacked a little flavor. I'm not sure which it is. My friend and I ordered the Duk Bok Ki, Kim Chi Chi Gae, and sauteed squid with vegetables (forgot the Korean name). All three were supposed to be spicy....but I couldn't taste the spice. It was quite disappointing really. =\ Still, we managed to eat up all the food anyway because we were hungry, and we just enjoy Korean food in general.

The owner is so sweet though. Like Brian P. has already mentioned, the owner is very tough and versatile! She is pretty much a one-woman show; she has a cook helping her a little bit, but I think she does most of the work anyway. She was very attentive to my friend and me, making sure we had enough rice and that our food was okay. So, service is pretty much 4-5 stars for me.

The atmosphere of the restaurant is quiet, intimate--dim lights, and cushions for the "booth" seats along the walls. The bathroom hallway was kind of creepy, strangely enough; it was a very thin hallway leading up to a small thin bathroom...felt like I was entering into a small house or something on Charlie and the Chocolate Factory.

The restaurant was a bit empty when we went for dinner, but it was already 7pm or so anyway. Um Ma Son is located in a quieter area of Geary anyway, so I can understand the slower rate of customers going by. 

Well, I sure hope Um Ma Son still gets decent business though, because the owner really is so very sweet. I hope we just went on an off-day, and that the food really is more flavorful than it was yesterday....maybe we just chose the wrong dishes, I don't know. I guess I'll see next time!
author: Helene K.

description:
This place is cool....Came with a group of friends and there was only one worker. The lady that took our order was also the cook.  However, the service was great. She was able to multi-task. 

I am a big fan of jap chae. It was okay here. It was a little bit too oily. We had a order of bulgogi and it was a little bit to salty . I had to drink tons of water. She was also nice and gave us free soda....The place wasnt pack at all. i think its because it looks so dim inside and the shades are also up.  The spicy calarami is good. The price is not bad at all.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Um Ma Son? More like Um Ma God! But that statement is regarding "the show," not necessarily the food. So what is the show? No, Um Ma Son does not have acrobats blowing flame out their mouths while balancing your sizzling kalbi dish at the tip of a stick on top of their heads while Siberian tigers chase them around the restaurant. No, Um Ma Son's show is way better than that baloney. Um Ma Son has a little mama-san who... answers the phone, greets you at the door, refills your water, takes your order, cooks your food, serves your food, wipes your tables, washes your dishes, runs your credit card, converses with you, rubs your belly and blows you kisses from across the kitchen. Okay I'm lying about the last two on that list, but really that one little old lady who runs this shop is definitely the show of the restaurant. If there was an award for "Best Multitasker of All Time," she definitely would win it. I could not believe how one little old lady was capable of running this entire restaurant, while still managing to get everyone's food out without exceeding a 25 minute wait. Despite there being 6 other parties in the restaurant, this little old lady tended to everyone's needs punctually. Bravo!

The food was acceptable, however little old mama-san steered us away from our original orders. I'm not too sure if that was her tactic to make her multitasking run more smoothly, but she definitely manipulated us into making us order what she wanted to cook. We wanted to order the grilled short ribs (kalbi), but she made us order the steamed chopped short ribs instead. We wanted to order the fried potstickers (mandu), but she insisted on having us order the steamed potstickers instead. In the words of mama-san, "ohhh no, dis wan bet-tah!" followed by an irresistible old lady smile. Hmm, was little mama-san trying to make her workload more easier? I think so! But I don't blame her since she was a one man team. The food was ordinary. Nothing mind blowing. The kalbi was flavorful, however if it was the actual short ribs with the middle bone, I think I would've enjoyed them more. The mandu were tasty, however they lacked that crispy crunch I was craving that the fried mandu would have provided. The Kimchee fried rice was so-so, but it worked as a good filler between the mandu and kalbi. Some of the side dishes (banchan) were delicious, while some others looked like baby fetus parts. Although the food didn't strike me as being the greatest, I really enjoyed Um Ma Son's little mama-san.
author: Ally C.

description:
I do like Korean food in general.
This place,
A hard working Korean old lady doing every thing.
cooking, serve, everything.
And she is very well mannered.
but she said to me, " Thank you Ma'am".
Please do not misunderstand me here.
I am not making fun of her.
OKey!?
I think she is still learning English like I am.
I like Korean people too even they have a reputation of a" hot temper".
My son loves this place.
So I don't want say anything bad.
But I ordered Fish.
That was a big mistake.
It was a kim-chee flavored steamed red snapper. Yuck! ( I always spelled "Yak")
It was bad. cost me $14 but I just could not eat it.
I took it home because I did not want to embarrass anybody.
I felt bad but I had to threw it away.
but, over all,
I give 4. and I like to see this place gets popular because the lady.
Go girl!
author: Nobu K.

description:
Great Korean food.  BBQ chicken was awesome, and who doesn't love all the little plates they give you?  Kimchee and pickled cucumber and spicy bean sprouts!  I passed on the little plate full of tiny fish, though.  All those little eyeballs staring up at me.  No thank you.

The service was great.  Very nice lady.  Its a little pricey for dinner, but they have a good lunch special until 3.  We actually got there a little after 3, but she let us have the lunch rate anyway.  Will definitely return.
author: Starla D.

description:
An unexpected surprise here - really kickass dumpling soup.  Just imagine potstickers in the best broth you've ever had.  Mmmm.  It's the #30 I believe.   As for the the other stuff, I thought good but not great, but then again I'm not expert on Korean food.  The clay pot was pretty solid, but just had something a little off.  

Can be a good cheap late-night eat, with many of the plates going for $10.
author: John H.

description:
I actually didn't really try their entrees but I did have their chicken wings and and seafood pancake. It was really delicious and this place was actually the first Korean restaurant where I had my first seafood pancake.
I also tried their strawberry soju which was sooo goooooooood. It didn't even taste like alcohol, just fruit punch or something.

This place is kind of small but has a homey feeling to it. Nice waiters and nice decor.
author: Tracy A.

description: We've been here a few times for dinner.  The owner is awesome.  Super nice and friendly.  She does it all.  From taking our order to cooking the food!  The only one item I've tried that I wasn't all that impressed with was the kim chee fried rice...everything else is awesome.  Parking in this area can be difficult.
author: Stella C.

description:
Ordered:

1. Kimchi Tofu Soup - very delicious, perfect for a cold night
2. Kimchi Pancake - crispy goodness
3. Kalbi Jjim (did i just butcher that?) - this was amazing. the meat was tender and sweet and with the addition of the potatoes on the side.... i thought about this dish for DAYS. 

The place is cozy, and the food tasted like it came from a mothers recipe book. I will definitely be coming back for more.
author: Jessica C.

description:
One of the most memorable experiences I have ever had. I went late tonight with my girlfriend. In terms of service, ambiance and quality of food we both gave it 5 stars! 

We ordered the seafood pancakes (the best I've ever had), the dumpling soup and a modified bi bim bab. Even though I'm white, I've had enough homecooked Asian foods to tell what amazing homecooked food tastes like and your grandma couldn't get closer to homecooked tastes than what you get here!!!

We felt like honored guests! We were the only people there at the time, and after saying a few words to the chief/server in Korean about how tasty the food was, I think I became her honorary grandson. The entire time she basically did everything short of putting the food in our mouths for us! Let's just say we gave her a 100% tip on a $40 meal and we felt more than honored to do so! So go here and support my new grandma!!! :)
author: Isaiah W.

description:
The entire Richmond/Pac Hts area is a total dead zone after 8pm, especially once you get out of the China-cluster on Clement and 5th...so keep on driving and driving in the darkness...and here is Um Ma Son, open till real late, to take you in.

Food is ok, the pancake with seafood is really flavorful, jap chae is regular, the side dishes are not spectacular but ok, the sundobu is usually a hit. Had bbq once and it was normal.

The place is absolutely no frills, momma-run, and unpretentious (although the prices are SO san francisco.) So why bother coming here more than once? Well, it's a simple eat..and did I mention that it's the only place that is open at night (with decent food) in this zombie-land called Richmond? 

I miss KTown in LA
author: Paolo D.

description: My favorite Korean restaurant so far. The pajun, kalbi, and rice cake soup is the bomb. The chef/owner is super nice.
author: Mary L.

description:
The waitress lady does a great job serving, and they're open super late by SF standards. 

I ordered the kimchee fried rice + pork + eggs combo, but wasn't super impressed. (though preparation was QUICK!) I'm sure their soup items are better. I live right around there so I'll be sure to update soon.
author: Jae K.

description: Great food, AMAZING SERVICE ,  serves beer and sake, and must try their tofu soup
author: Tree W.

description:
Um ma son is a gem in the outer richmond.  The place has some of the best bibimbop in town.  The portions are huge and the service is stellar.  

The restaurant, as mentioned before, is ran by two korean ladies.  When you tell the server your order, you see the older lady run to the back and prepare your dish as if you were at home.  Before you take the first bite, the same lady will refill your glasses with water and hand you utensils.  She asked my freind if the noodles were difficult to handle with his chopsticks, therefore she came and cut them right in front of us with a kitchen shear!

They have a fairly extensive menu, and all korean beers and shochyu.
Did I mention that they are open until 2 am, so if you are in the neighborhood, drop by for a late night meal!
author: Ishmael V.

description: Came here a couple days ago after a hike up Alamere Falls...it had good reviews and we were all craving tofu soup! When we got here it was pretty empty. There was only one lady doing all the work. I ordered #27 seafood tofu-Spicy. I was in a group of 5 and my food came pretty fast! I liked the side dishes, especially the spicy fish cakes. The actual tofu soup was ok. I thought mine could of been a little more spicy. The kimchi was alright, I've tried better.
author: Avinika S.

description:
Great, homey Korean place.  The people that run this place are really nice.

We got the (1) seafood pancake; (2) spicy pork; and (3) hot tofu soup (spicy).  All three were really great.  The seafood pancake was fried well and had a lot of good ingredients.  The hot tofu soup was flavored really well (although not really all that spicy).  I loved the homey, attentive service as well.  The lady gave us extra fish cake because we said we really liked fish cake.

Also, this is one of the few places where I actually LIKE the kimchi.

I'm coming back here for sure!
author: John T.

description:
Food:  Ummason serves the best Spicy BBQ Pork in the city.  It is good quality meat, marinated in spicy sauce.  I wish I have the recipe so I can make some of my own.  The grill fish and battered shrimp appetizer are very good as well.  The Tofu soup is also pretty darn good.   

Atmosphere:
It is small, and usually empty and thus I agree with Theo T. that this is one of the best kept secret.    The music is a mix of top 40 US/dance and top Korean hits.   The owner does most of the work herself.  She is very friendly and keeps the atmosphere lively.
author: Tom L.

description: I had #28 a soup with dumplings, rice cake, beef on the bone.  It was great light and subtle home-cooked feeling food.  I like this place for the food better than Toyose and Arang although, I suppose those two places have more action.
author: Jason D.

description: quite expensive. poor service, poor ambience. This place was much worse than the one I have in my town, Bakersfield (such a small town). Not so many side dishes. My hubsband ordered seafood tofu soup but there was no seafood at all. I would never go back again. very very disappointing.
author: Min S.

description:
You would never know walking by that this place is golden. Most of the times I've passed by there have been little patrons... but don't be fooled. If you've come looking for a nice home cooked meal, you've come to the right place. You can tell that the food is made straight from the heart and soul of the owner. Give her a lot of credit for running her own one woman show.

The bibimbap in the stone bowl is absolutely amazing. The char from the bottom of the rice mixed in with creamy egg yolk and hot sauce is just what the doctor ordered. I drool just recapping my experience there. The beef soondubu was also really good. The tofu is so silky and soft... broth is perfect enough to drink at the end of the meal.

I am so thankful that this restaurant is less than two blocks away from my apartment so I can order take out whenever I want. But even if you live far, it's worth it! Support the business... it is well deserved!

Five stars... not only for the good food, because the owner is super woman. Closed on Mondays, but on all other days open until 2am.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
Um ma Son is a little tiny family-oriented Korean restaurant.  Comes complete with a clean home-ly atmosphere, delicious food, and fast-friendly service.

The main courses follows with all side dishes.  Mmmm, Mmmm Good!  I love the anchovies...esp over rice!  Their Soondubu and Rice Cake soup is the Bomb.  And to top it off, some good soju...esp the "Green Bottles"...*giggle*.  

The prices won't kill you.  It is considered cheaper than other Korean restaurants ( a HUGE plus!!! ).  

Great place, makes you feel like home, The staff (mom/daughter), oh so friendly!  They treat you like family.  Definitely no segregation.  This is something I have never experienced in any other Korean restaurant.

In fact, I will go there tonight!
author: Toma W.

description:
If you're looking for some homemade cooking this is the spot. The owner is super nice and friendly. Since i've been going there for over 2 years now and am a regular she often treats me to a beer! How many other restaurants do that to their customers? Anyways this place is definitely a hidden gem in the Richmond. Here are some personal recomendations:

1. Kalbi Tang. The short-ribs in this soup are super tender. Other places usually give you hard rubbery meat (meaning they cooked it quick) but here it's slow-cooking to get the meat very tender.

2. Tofu Soup. I always tell her to make it spicy and the flavoring is just awesome!

3. Gin Man Du. Steamed potstickers are homemade and taste great.

Give this place a try if you've been meaning too and if not sure what to order try my recomendations!!!



My usuals here are the steamed potstickers (MAN DU GU),
author: George L.

description:
small...narrow...interior...probably is one of the smallest korean restaurants in sf....it's clean...and has a "cute" korean interior...sorry..i thought it was a bit childish...was i expecting too much?...i mean...all the raving 4 and 5 star reviews...but came out a bit disappointed...

um ma son (mom's hand)...comes fighting with a variety of traditional bbq dishes....stews....fish....stir fries...soups...and mixed dishes...the problem...she also packs big restaurant prices..yes prices comparable to top sf korean bbq restaurants.......

taste and seasoning seems right...but lacks "umph"...the special "oh so good" feeling....meat marinade is done right to perfection..but definitely needs to cook at higher temperature and faster...sear the flavors into the meat...side dishes seem fresh and okay..all good..but need something special..(good raw spicy crab?...maybe a fish?...salty spicy raw clams?)...i don't know...for the price...need something that catches my attention...
author: Hen A.

description:
There are so many Korean restaurants along Geary Blvd nowadays, all going for the hip and trendy look, but this one feels like being at home. It's small and cozy meaning that service is attentive, and the people working there are extremely friendly. Another plus is that it closes at 2am everyday - even on weekdays, even on Sundays.

My favorites are the chap jae, the shortribs (not very fatty) and fried chicken wings.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description: One of my favorite Korean joints in the city. Consistently good food and friendly service. The store is run by a sweet lady who takes orders then runs back to the kitchen to cook your food! My favorites are the dot sol bibimbap and kimchi pancake. All soooo good!
author: Cee J.

description: The decor of this place is pretty awesomely standard modern Korean (unlike some of the other ones down Geary, i.e. Brothers or Korean Village) the food isn't bad but isn't super-great either, since I don't remember anything about the side dishes or sundofu I ordered.  The lady is extremely nice though.  This is a good place to go to if you're craving Korean food when you see it, but not really a destination except at 1 AM 'coz they're open 'til 2. (unless you feel like driving up to that Charcoal BBQ place on 10th or 11th.)
author: David A.

description: It's great. The ajumma who run the place remind me of the little places I use to go to in Seoul. The complimentary banchan (small table dishes) are very good, which I consider the foremost factor in rating a Korean restaurant. The jiggae was also very good. I ordered Bi Bim Bap and it was good...its a large serving, enough for two. It's reasonably priced and they serve HIte and OB beer. It's not a BBQ place so don't expect samgyeopsal or galbi...BTW still searching for a place closer than Korea Town Los Angeles that has good samgyeopsal.
author: Anton L.

description:
A few of my friends and I decided to check out this restaurant on a quiet Sunday evening (based on rave reviews on Yelp) and to see if could match the amazing culinary skills of my own umma.  The mother and daughter duo warmly welcomed us in Korean -  there were no other patrons aside from us so it kinda felt like we were hanging out at a friend's house.  Very quiet and chill.  Not the frenzied chaos that is Brothers. 

Between the five of us we ordered a soon-doo-boo jikae, kimchi jikae, chicken bbq, bulgogi, and hemul pachun.  The haemul pahjun (seafood pancake) was to die for.  Golden chrispy goodness on the outside, tender calamari bits & veges on the inside.  The soon-boo-jikae was fairly good with a raw egg cracked & put in when it arrived bubbling at our table.  

The sides (save for the kehnip) and the gogi were a bit disappointing - they just didn't pack a punch in terms of favor.  The banchan seemed really bland.  And I guess I like my meats with the carcinogens seared in. 

I will have to revisit, perhaps for lunch, and try the homemade mandoos.
author: Melissa S.

description: The best Korean in town. The owner is the sweetest woman in the world and always takes great care of us when we go! A must try in the Richmond!
author: George W.

description:
I was craving for Bi bim bap and there was a new Korean restaurant that opened two blocks from where I live. I think they've been open for about four months. I go inside around 7pm and I'm the only guest. I ordered the meal that I was craving for and while I was waiting, to my happy surprise, I was served complimentary tea and soup while I waited for my hot, steaming pot of beef, vegetables and egg. The bottom of the pot had crunchy rice just like I wanted. They served 7 side dishes to be eaten with the entree: pickled cucumber, pickled radish, kimchi, pickled sesame leaves, garlic bean sprouts, sauteed fish cakes and spicy anchovies.

When I first saw the bowl, I thought that there wouldn't be enough rice for all the food. But by the time I've eaten half of it, I started to feel really full. I still ate the whole thing, happily stuffed, since taking it to go wouldn't taste as good. When the bill came, I was served desert, also complimentary. The waitress was really nice too. She spoke good Korean as some native customers came in for a meal. 

The lady sitting behind a counter went into the kitchen and started cooking for me. When she was done she came back out and watched to see if I was enjoying it from the counter. This just showed how much there care about the reactions of customers. I read in Chowhound that the mother is the cook and the daughter is the waitress.

I know it's a little ambitious to give a restaurant four stars after only one visit, but this place is really nice to come to when you just want good homemade Korean cooking. The only down side is that the kimchi and pickled dishes weren't that spicy for me. They were flavorful but I felt like there may have been too much garlic and it made me want to go home right away to brush my teeth.

Bi bim bop around $9.95 for dinner. I think $5 for lunch.
Tea, soup, dessert and 7 side dishes: free.
author: Eriko W.

description: I like the food here a lot. There is a good selection of korean street food as well as a few more traditional dishes. I can't speak to how this will taste to true Koreans but to me, I really enjoyed it. It tastes a lot like home cooking, which I really appreciate.
author: Andrew H.

description: I came here with a friend about two weeks ago and have been meaning to write a review.  We weren't really hungry and only ordered a couple of items. We had kimchi fried rice and korean rice cake.  Both items were good and we finished the plates. The only complaint I have is that they should make the portion a little bigger. I will come back next time when I happen to be in the city.
author: Anh W.

description:
My favorite Korean restaurant in the city!! I've been constantly coming here for over 2 years. My friends and I always order the same food and we recently come here every week.

I love how the mama (the elder lady) is always so nice and warming even though she doesn't speak much English. She makes the best dishes too!! 

Kal Bi Tang: The best one I've ever had. Me and my husband travel a lot and every city every korean restaurant we go to we always order Kal Bi Tang, but none of them can beat Um Ma Son's!!!

Soft Tofu Soup: Great taste. I love how she uses soft tofu when some other restaurants use the regular ones. This makes a difference.

Jap Chae: The best one too. She always cooks it with lots of veges and this is why I love it so much because it makes the taste so much delicious. There's always some extra soup on the plate so the noodles stay soft and tasty instead of dried and hard. 

It is very sad that I never see this restaurant being packed since the food is so good. However, I do like how it is always quiet and peaceful so we can enjoy our meals and chat. Um Ma Son is not a fancy restaurant, but definitely a good family style one.
author: Lisa L.

description:
One word: delicious!

I've been here now a total of five times, and each time was pretty memorable. The first time, which I suppose was a year or two ago I ordered pretty blindly not knowing what to get. The most memorable part of it was the waitress taking our photo... don't know what for, but she took it. We all assumed that when we would come back here someday our photo would be up. None the less, we went away satisfied. I had those bbq short ribs. Good.

The other times I've been here it's been for parties! People love this place for parties. We took up the whole right side with the tables, and I have to say everyone pretty much ordered the same thing: the bi bim bap and the ... well, I hate that I don't remember the name, but it's the #40!! And it's so good... noodles, meat, mushrooms, etc. Those were the money makers. Those were really good. 

And last night, it was still good. I ventured into soup this time because it was cold and rainy outside, and I craved something hot and tofu. The spicy tofu soup was nice and hot (temperature and spice wise) and it was very satisfying. Me and my friends enjoyed sharing this dish, though I made sure I got the most of it because well, I'm really greedy.

The service, as always was great. Yeah, we were the only ones in there for a while, but still the waitress/owner/cook (she does everything... seriously) was really nice and tentative. She made some light conversation with us and made sure were were enjoying our food (which we were). She also told us to be careful when we go outside because it was raining really hard at the time. It was like she was our mother. And that was cool.
author: Caroline L.

description:
I grew up in Koreatown in LA, so I know full well that I shouldn't bother looking for good Korean food elsewhere. Though it doesn't compare (and nothing can), I can't find anything wrong with this place.

The restaurant's name translates to "Mama's Hands" in English, and that's exactly the feeling I get when I eat here. I've been there three times in close to a year and the lady managed to recognize me. I've been there late enough so she'd be the only one cooking, and the food still came out hot and in a timely manner. It's not as gutsy or familiar as K-town cuisine, but it's close enough to home and I'm always happy to come back.

Definitely one of the better Korean restaurants in the Bay Area with some unbeatable hours.
author: Bihn K.

description: kalbi jim (takes about 20 min) and the dolsot bibimbap!
author: Helen Y.

description: The food and service was great!  A great place to enjoy late food.  I was impressed by the owner at the restaurant because she did it all - waitress, cook, and service.  The food tasted really good and spicy.  The place is a little far into the Richmond district, but worth going again.
author: Saul G.

description: Cheap, CLEAN, and ran by an extremely nice lady, and it's open until 2AM. what more is there? The food is spicy and tasty.
author: Kellen C.

description:
I live around Um Ma Son so it's nice to have some place to go at 12 AM in the morning when I'm getting the munchies. If you're looking for some good food during a late-night and you have money... Um Ma Son is the place to go.  I've been here countless times and I'm still craving for their tofu soup.
I love their tofu soup! It's amazing. Different than the ones you would normally have at a different restaurant but really good regardless. 
Their bibimbap is mediocre but when I'm craving for some bibimbap it satisfies my hunger.
Jap Chae is really good there too.
The chicken wings are oh so juicy too!
My favorite part is that Um Ma Son's owner is so nice and friendly. I've been in there when she has a lot of customers but she still treats everyone with the same kindness she would when I would walk in and no customers are in there.
author: Carina L.

description:
If my mother, who is  incredibly talented in the kitchen, ever opened a korean restaurant in SF, this is exactly what it would be like.
Yuk ke jang and soon do bu ji gae........so tasty and flavorful.
Even the ribs were yummy.  I love that the lady is the one who cooks and serves.  she's very sweet.  can't WAIT to try the chicken thing where it takes 3 hours too cook and you need to call ahead?!!!
author: Rio K.

description:
I moved to San Francisco from Los Angeles where the Korean food is better than the food from the homeland. I was pleasantly surprised to walk into Umma Son and find a nicely-decorated, clean, mom-daughter restaurant. Their side dishes (banchan) are yummy and fresh, which is a must for me. I've tried their kimchee fried rice, which was a little greasy and their bibimbop didn't have that sesame flavor that I love. I usually go for their tofu soup. Nontheless, their food is solid and I would recommend to anyone who is a fan of good ol-fashioned Korean food. 

P.S. I miss the days when you served us green onion pancakes and shik-hye (a sweet rice dessert drink) on the house!
author: Jane C.

description:
FOOD .75 star
Panchan - Slightly bummed that they wait to serve you panchan until just before (or just as) they deliver your meal. Good business choice for them, though because I'm sure I'm not the only customer who gets full on kimchi and fish cakes.
I had the Vegetarian Tofu Stew (which is a misnomer because I can taste the fish broth; not that I'm complaining about it - just letting the vegetarians know if this is a problem for you) - the egg is already in the bowl when they bring it to you - I guess that's better, but a) I like the ritual of doing it myself and b) what if I was scared of eggs right now? The broth was surprisingly soupy for how spicy it was. Big chunks of zucchini was the supporting character to the Tofu. It was not bad, but not the best I've had either.
My date had the Dolsot BiBimbap. He got a tablespoon's equivalent of meat in that large bowl - this wouldn't have bothered me, but I know he'd prefer that the meat was served up in the same quantity as each of the servings of vegetables in the bowl. Oh, and the kochujang was really watered down.

SERVICE .5 star
I can't tell if the girl who served us genuinely didn't understand us or just decided that she couldn't before she even approached us, but seems like it definitely set the stage for the level of service we received.

When the bibimbap came, I asked for some kochujang for my date and she looked at me confused. Then I showed a squeezing motion with my hand over his bowl, followed by the words "Kochujang" (I said it twice first pronouncing the first letter as a K, then as a G) and "Sauce?" (yes, said with a question mark). Then, without acknowledgement, she walked off and I could hear her saying "sauce" to the lady in the kitchen who then walked out to find the Kochujang at another table and delivered it to us.
I asked that same server for an egg, making a cracking motion over my boiling soup when she brought my tofu stew. Again, confusion on her face followed by an abrupt departure and yelling of "egg?!" in the back kitchen. She came back saying, "it's inside".
Honestly, she wasn't rude or unfriendly; just seemed a little unsure of herself and maybe of what I was asking her for. I give her half a star for trying and the other half will come after she's had a chance to work on it.

PRICE .5
There are better places around town for about the same price, but it's certainly not the worst I've had.

HOURS +1
1 extra star for being open late, even though we weren't there that late (just the fact that they are gives me comfort knowing i can get tofu stew somewhere in town when I'm craving it at 1 in the morning).

LOCATION .75
Half a star for being off a major bus line and another .25 star for being close to post-dinner dessert locations and around the corner from a movie theater (yayy!)

minus .25 star for the drivers - if you're driving, parking is a bit of a chore around there - there's a lot with meters one block east, but the meters run until midnight!!!
author: Kariz M.

description:
maybe soondubu isn't their thing, but pretty disappointing.  so nothing else is open around 2am, but ajima was very nice
the teapot of bori cha was actually really good
haemul soondubu unfortunately was watery, weak seafood, not spicy (when asked for it), had to ask for the egg, etc...
oh well, LA K town has spoiled me
author: Rob C.

description:
I am pretty surprised that this restaurant has gotten such good reviews. I really liked the feel of the restaurant at the first glance -- it was a cozy and a nice middle age woman welcomed us in. I was unimpressed by the appetizers there were two bean sprouts one original and one spicy so the variety was lacking.  I ordered three dishes that have been raved about on yelp: the seafood pancake, the kimchee soup with rice, and bi bim bap. The sea food pancake  was fine. The bi bim bap was also fine, although it was bland and seriously had two tiny pieces of meat in it. So I guess it's good if you want to go vegetarian. The kimchee soup was AWFUL. It was so salty I had to drain the rice from the soup in order to eat it. And again it had two small pieces of meat. I thought it was strange why the woman hadn't asked me if I wanted beef or pork, I guess it doesn't matter since you can't really see or taste it anyway. This is all taking into accountr that I hadn't eaten all day and I would have tolerated any decent food, but this was just really sub par. 

As we got ready to ready, we gave her a $40 for our meal of $34.50. we  waited for 5-10 minutes until we realized that she wasn't going to give us change. When  we did ask for change, she deliberately gave us a $5 bill and 50 cents which forced us to tip ~18%. 

I think this restaurant has definitely turned me off from Korean food for a while.
author: Lily Z.

description:
Arrived here on a Friday night.

We had a party of about 11 people, and my party of 4 was the first to arrive.  We were waiting on the rest of our friends, and the waitress kept continuously asking us every 5 minutes if we were ready to order.  Why would I order if the rest of my party is not present?  I thought that was kinda pestering.

Anywho, I ordered a Bibimbap.  The portions were a lot smaller than I anticipated, but still good.  But please, emphasize the "a lot smaller."  Also, they seemed to have confused my friend's order and made him wait.

Probably wouldn't go back to this place.
author: Leslie Y.

description:
The food here was nothing exceptional at all.  Not note worthy in the slightest.  The kimchi was disgusting.  Don't get me wrong.  I love all types of kimchi, whether it is my mom's, fresh, a week old, jarred, homemade, or winter kimchi (super fermented and saved to eat in the winter when there is limited fresh cabbage to make fresh kimchi).  This kimchi went untouched.  The rest of the panchan (the collection of side dishes you receive with entrees) was mediocre.

I ordered the chapchae (glass noodles) and dueje bulgogi (spicy pork).  The dueje bulgogi was OK.  It wasn't bad, but it wasn't great.  The chapchae was off.  I wouldn't recommend ordering it.

As for the service, for a small location, service was very slow.  It was about half full.  I know that it is a mother-daughter duo running it, and it was really cute to hear the daughter calling to her mother everytime customers left so the mother could say goodbye to each customer.  I'm very understanding and accommodating when a restaurant is busy, as I have worked in a restaurant.   But the service was ridiculous.  

I will not go back there.  But I gave them a two star rating because I reserve 1 ratings for significantly horrible places.  And this place just wasn't good.  Perhaps different time will provide better service, and maybe you can have better luck with the food if you order something different?
author: MiYong E.

description:
we came here by searching for lunch on our mobiles..

What a great find!

The elder woman who was there was so kind and nice to us. She took our order (we were the only ones there) and went in the kitchen to cook it herself.

She didn't speak much english but was very nice.

We ate family style, including claypot rice, rice cake noodles and tender pork!

I'd come back anytime!
author: Hien T.

description:
The minimal interior and the name ("Mom's Hand") makes it a homey place.  But you're still going to smell like Korean after you're done.

The soon dooboo was pretty good; mandoo had way too much sugar, and the mackerel was okay as well.  The menu listed some impressive items that you don't normally see in many places.  Among these include a chestnut/chicken soup (must be pre-ordered) and the sam gyup sal, which I saw a uniformly large group of lily white types devour.  Sam Gyup Sal refers to the 3 layers of fat and meat of pork.  It looks and smells like bacon.  

The pudgy family was very happy, so I guess that deserves a star.
author: ed y.

description:
There are only 2 things about this place:
1) Opens late
2) The friendly owner, not her daughter.

Food is medicore, if not worse. Only Yuk-Gye-Jang and Gal-Bi-Tang were good, the rest didn't taste authentic at all... and that means I didn't like. But those 2 dishes mentioned were very good.

The owner is really nice, but other people in this restaurant is simply annoying and that makes this place less attractive.

Why do I go? Because it's the closest Korean place from my apartment and I can go when I don't want to cook in the middle of the night. If they can serve more better food and give some better service from other people than the "mom", then it should be at least a 4-star place...
author: Andrew Y.

description:
I like this restaurant for the cozy, homey feel it has, the wonderful complimentary shikhye (sweet rice drink) you get for dessert, and the side dishes.  Of the handful of Korean restaurants I've been to in city, I'd have to say I like the side dishes here the best....fresh kimchi, seasoned bean sprouts, spicy fish cakes, and so on.  Our server (who also cooked our food...I think she was the owner) was incredibly sweet and often came back to see if we liked the food and to refill our drinks.  

Now on to the main dishes.  I had the bibimbap and my boyfriend had the bulgogi.  We both felt these were just all right.  The egg in the bibimbap was barely cooked (like flame kissed) and both the egg white and yolk were runny, which made me somewhat concerned.  I didn't get dolsot bibimbap either, so its not like the egg got a chance to cook later on.  Though there were a variety of ingredients, I didn't feel the bibimbap had a lot of flavor and had to add a lot of hot sauce to get some taste to it.  My boyfriend thought his bulgogi was all right, but kind of bland.  Then again, we are both from LA and haven't yet come across a Korean restaurant in the Bay thats as good as those in the LA K-town.

Though we weren't really impressed with the main dishes, we'd go back for the great service, the side dishes and to give it another try.  I'd recommend going at lunch...the prices range from about $7-9 per dish.
author: Swirls L.

description:
This place is ok. I always order their tofu stew. Tofu house in Santa Clara is way better. The tofu comes out in big chunks which i kind of don't like because then there's a lot of liquid and it feels watery to me. The taste is decent. They only give you one bowl of rice so if you're really hungry you're going to have to keep asking them to bring you out more. I've never had to wait when i wanted to eat here but parking is a real pain. I can circle around for 40 minutes on a weekday looking for a spot. 

I really like the spicy rice cakes appetizer, but the portion is really small.

I would recommend this place if you're itching for korean food. But if you want really good korean food, go to Santa Clara.
author: Terry D.

description:
Came here for dinner and got to say I love it. We were greeted and seated right away. Unlike other Korean restaurants, we got the little appetizer dishes quickly - fish cake, kim chee, bean sprouts, etc.  The waitress even offered us seconds for the fish cake and kim chee. 

We ordered :
1) Seafood Soft Tofu Soup (spicy) 
The tofu soup had the right flavor to it -  not too spicy; no MSG but ACTUAL soup - there's not much places where you can get that these days.  Tofu was very soft and fresh.  I swear it's better than the tofu soups at Tofu House! 

2) Seafood Pancake 

Both were DELICIOUS!!! 

It's a small place which means no waiting (compared to Tofu House).  Nice place for small groups.  It was a little hard to understand what the waitress (I'm assuming it's the owner since it's the older lady) was saying in the beginning but you'll get use to it - she's very friendly.

I would definitely come here again. Great place for late nights since it opens until 2 AM.

GREAT Tofu Soup +1
Seconds +1
Friendly & Fast Service +2
author: Joanna W.

description: I tried going here once and it was closed.  The hours said they would be open, but it was 6pm and no one was there.  I went back a few days later and it was pretty good.  They don't offer as many choices as I'm used to, but I managed to find something that would hit the spot.  The dish I ordered was really spicy.  I'm used to eating spicy foods, but it was so spicy that I couldn't finish it because my mouth was just tasting fire and nothing else.  The portion was generous though, so that's good.  The side dishes were my favorite part, especially the dried sardines.  I think I just ordered the wrong dish, but I'd definitely go back and try something else.  The service was good, but then again there was no one else in there.  I also liked that they played K-pop over the sound system.
author: k h.

description:
This place opened up recently and boy...I AM SILLY HAPPY!

It's unlike any other Korean restaurant I have been to in the city because it's REAL korean food.  It's the food my mom was making when I was growing up.  Everything on the menu was something that only a Korean mom can make!  The service is really awesome, too.  If you feel like experiencing a homecooked Korean meal and you don't know any Korean families, this is the place to go!
author: Keika L.

description:
I  come here often enough the waitress and the mom can recognize me and know our orders. Whats better then that! well its open late! and its yummmie!! Its nice they are catering to the audience, its also especially nice that the food is damn tastey!!

I recommnet going with anything on the menu, but if your hungry be sure to get the bi bim bap. Rice is binding!! Kimchi BINDING!
author: Brian Y.

description: Two thumbs up!!!!! I'm Korean but I highly recommend this place as the best Korean restaurant in S.F. The price is reasonable and the food is sooo yummy. The owner never ever put MSG at allllll!!! If you are looking for good and healthy Korean food, come here and enjoy!!!
author: Joyce P.

description:
I've been there a couple of times. I'm sure I'll be back again.

I'm not korean, so I don't have much comparison to other restaurants. But, good food is good food. And, they are good. Pair that up with great service, and it's heaven! You've got to try the soup!

Cozy place, nice people.
author: Martin L.

description: The owner did a great job with every part of this place, its small and cozy, great customer service and amazing food! The little lady that runs the place is soo sweet and always offers to get you more until you can't eat anymore. It's def woth the month!
author: Tonia P.

description: Can't comment on the food, but this was probably the worst service I've ever experienced. Came in for dinner literally starving after a day of fasting and got a table by myself. Waitress gave me some tea and a menu and then proceeded to ignore me for the next 15 minutes. What happened next might have been amusing had I not been so hungry. I flagged down the waitress and asked if I could order and pointed to the menu. Clearly her English skills weren't top notch, since she proceeded to bring me a glass of water. Sort of rhymes I guess.  I asked again and she appeared not to understand that I was there to eat and not drink tea and water and stare at the menu all night. Ten minutes later, I grabbed the other waitress and asked if I could order. She brought over a note pad but no pen, started to chuckle, left and proceeded to help other customers. I have in the past felt on rare occasions, some sense of discrimination for being a Caucasian customer in a basically Asian oriented restaurant, but never like this. It did appear that a group of probably Korean women who walked in well after me and knew the waitress, were about to get served before me. One would have to conclude that they didn't want to serve me, since they were competent enough to serve others there. I tried to figure out how I had offended them by asking to order, but Hunger got the better of me and I had to bail, but let some customers who were waiting outside know what they could expect, like I'm telling you right here.
author: Barry F.

description: I should start by telling everyone how horrible it is so i can continue to get seated quickly!  But i can't do that since I love the woman who runs this place dearly!  I can't tell you how much I enjoy getting my food nice and hot!  The kitchen is quick, efficient and attentive.  I don't Yelp a whole lot but I think I should start since I eat out ALL the time!  A little place like Um Ma Son deserves the praise it gets, they do a good job!
author: Amorette K.

description:
This is my favorite Korean restaurant to go when I'm craving for Korean food. I love love LOVE their TOFU soup! The tofu is silky smooth and the broth isn't over salted. I adore the banchans too. 

The woman (the owner) does EVERYTHING (cooking, cleaning, waitressing, EVERYTHING)! She is the sweetest and most loving lady ever. She remembers what our (my family) usual dishes are before we even tell her and always serves us with a smile. She checks up on us frequently to ask how we are doing and to refill our tea. 

One time she saw me devouring the zucchini banchan. She laughed at me (in the grandma kind of way!) and brought out another one just for me! Told you she was the sweetest lady. Love love her!

The only negative thing about this establishment is that when the restaurant gets busy, it takes awhile for her to greet, take your orders, cook, or to get her attention.
author: S. H.

description:
I've had a yelp account for sometime now and haven't mustard up the energy to post a review until I now. What can I say...WOW!!! 

Got there after work around 11pm and this nice lady welcomes us in. The first impression I got was that this place was the "run of the mill" late nite korean joints that plague the Geary Street corridor (NASTY!!!). But to my surprise it was freakin' awesome. 

The food is good. Compared to those other late nite korean places its hands down the best! The thing that got me to want to write a review was the lady that runs the place. She sat us down got us menus and went to get us some tea. She then comes and takes our order and proceeds to go to kitchen where I thought she had to wake up the cooks since I didn't hear any noise coming out of it. But then you look in the kitchen and she's there cooking the food and in no time she comes out with the food and puts it on our table. Not only does she do all this she does it effortlessly, efficiently and with a smile. I was speechless. 

I'm in the restaurant business myself and have been doing it for 10 years. Like anything else you kinda get tired of it after awhile but after seeing this lady in action, it gives me new found inspiration and motivation to continue with my restaurant business. This lady deserves a "HIP HIP HOORAY!!!"  Keep up the good work Um Ma Son!
author: Tony H.

description: I went here with a group of friends one chilly night. We were starving and the only downside was parking was a biatch! But once we got in, we were warmly greeted with friendly service and hot tea. Its a small restaurant with a clean and simple decor. Our group tried a variety of dishes along with alcohol. All was yummy and filled our tummies well. I definitely wouldn't mind coming back here when I'm in the area and if I'm not driving. =)
author: Jenn C.

description: I like this place.  The people are super friendly and I really like the kimchee fried rice and fried chicken.  I usually get ths as take out.  When I do dine in I like the bi bim bap.  The prices are very reasonable too compared to other Korean restaurants.  Anyways, I will still be continuing coming here frequently since I live in the neighborhood.
author: A W.

description: Their food is good and fresh. With that being said, it does taste similar to a usual Korean restaurant. It is usually empty or close to it. I like how they close at 2am though. But one time I came at around 12:30 on a Friday and it was closed. Is business bad? ]= I think it's the location that they're in, it's hard to locate this small restaurant.
author: Chester H.

description: Good food and service.  This ma/pa restaurant is very cute and the atmosphere is very friendly.  Our kimchee was perfect and our soft tofu was wonderful as well.  I wouldn't have picked a different place for a good, warm new year's dinner.
author: Vitamin C.

description: The food reminded me of my Grandma cooking,  The spicy beef soup was great.  Had a good beef flavor and had a lot of beef.  The beef was very tender.   The spicy rice cake was a little sweet but good.  The kal bi was sizzling and nicely seasoned.  It's one lady who does everything.  Be patient, its well worth the wait.  Prices are average to below for Korean food.  I know have a new favorite for Korean food.  Thanks Jason for the recommenation.  Oh if you any kind of insurance, look up Jason Gee of Farmers (415) 566-2822.  Great rates and service.
author: don j.

description: Very homestyle, tasty food.  We brought our 3 kids there during the normal dinner hour (so no issues with trying to eat at midnight and finding it closed per other reviews).  It was just the one woman taking orders and cooking, which we thought was amazing, but she seems to have the system down.  She sold us heavy on getting some marinated beef even though we didn't want any, but it did turn out to be delicious so glad we got it.  Also got the rice cake soup which was awesome, soft tofu soup which was also quite good, chap chae (which was more watery than I'm used to so I would not order again), bi him bap in the stone bowl (really good).  Banchan were not the tastiest I've had in the world but totally fine.  It is a little pricey for the portions but all in all, a great, casual Korean meal with lots of flavor, and surprisingly prompt service given there was only one person working there!
author: Mae O.

description: Favorite Korean spot in Sf period. Warm welcoming vibe, fresh delicious food done just as you like...I'm so happy this is so close! Yummmmmmmmm!
author: Elizabeth G.

description: First time here and I don't think I would go back at least not for the Dol Sot Bi Bim Bap, or the Jap Chae.  The noodles in the Jap Chae were really oily and rubberly.  The vegetables it came with tasted like they had been sitting around for a while.  This is the same with the little dishes they bring in addition to the meal, i've just had better.  Personally can't say much about the Bi Bim Bap, but my friends were not raving about it.  Would venture there again and maybe try something else, but will likely stick to the Korean BBQ spots in the neighborhood.
author: Rowena Q.

description: I went here on a Sat nite for an early dinner with my girl and her one of her old coaches. We did it up family style, ordered a bunch of dishes and shared.  We also ordered a Soju cocktail which to me was basically some very yummy, semi-expensive juice. lol  This place feels very much like you are in a kitchen of ur mom if u are Korean. lol  It is a cozy little place that is an awesome "hole in the wall" place that not tat many people know about.  I would definitely come back but of course with Korean food it is a bit pricey.
author: Jonathan W.

description:
Um Ma Son is a great place -- cozy, homey foods, and wonderful service and owners.  I went with a large table a few times and the owner was very accommodating and the food well made.

It reminded me of the homey spots in Korea.

I'm going to address another reviewer's comment on service being overly-attentive.  That's normal in warm ancient cultures wherever you go: the Mediterranean (esp Italy), Korea, Latin America, among others.  In some countries, going to a family style restaurant means engaging with the owners and eating whatever special they put onto your table. The name of the place also indicates their philosophy of showing a mother's love through their cooking and hospitality.
author: S M.

description: My friend Wendy and her mom own and run this restaraunt, so I'm giving high scores... not just that, but their food kicks ass... Wendy's mom sure knows how to cook. I love going there after the gym around 9ish or so and getting some homemade potstickers or just some onion pancake and hanging out with Wendy (when she's not busy serving customers)... everything is made from scratch, so you know it's make with LOVE! Drop by sometime and check it out, it's home cooking - korean style!
author: Ms. T L.

description: The beef and chicken are kick butt good here. Yummy on an empty tummy! This place is open late at night so its a good place to kick back and eat! The kimchi is pretty good too. I avoid rice because I'm a main dish kinda guy.
author: Jason C. J.

description: we brought our own wine with us, no corkage. I substituted chicken for beef, no problem. food was delicious and plentiful and to top it all off, mama herself came out with a big smile.
author: Steph K.

description: One of the best korean cuisines i had for a long time. I've lived in San Francisco for all my life and i know mostly all the korean restaurants and nothing compares to Um Ma Son. I'm not a picky eater and when something tastes good, it's goes okay with me. The meat in their dishes is filled with flavor and i love the stews. Even though most of the menu are spicy dishes, i still enjoy every dish with full content. The place is small but it has a home feel to it. If the place was big, then it wouldn't have the home feel to it which kinds of deter the point of Um Ma Son. All i can say is that i love this place and the workers there treat me very kind.
author: Will C.

description:
the best service ever. she really take care of you.she can guess what you want^^ we feel like we are having dinner at home each time we go there. highly recommend the hotpot with pork and potatoes in it. we go there almost once a week because we miss korean auntie's food and her smile.
ps: the kimchi is 100% homemade by her, it's just awesome.
author: papamama l.

description: um ma son...family owned....a small place, but makes u feel like your at home.  i enjoyed their bbq chicken, fried chicken, and chap jae of course.  Service was excellent.  Me and my friends aways come here for a late night snack or perphaps a whole meal....cuz they open til 2 am. I take advantage of this cuz its rare where u can find a place opened this late in the richmond district.
author: stephanie n.

description: I order my food to go. The lady is nice and seems to run the place (cooking and service) by herself. She was nice enough to offer me tea while I waited for my food. I came home to eat my food and I have to say this is REALLY good Korean food. I thought I would be adventurous and order something different, so I ordered this dish that has rice cake, sauteed kim chee, and pork for 11 bucks (HIGHLY RECOMMEND IT!!!) The price is pretty good as well. Their gyoza aka. pot stickers are FRESH! and very good. One of the better Korean Restaurants in SF
author: Nick C.

description: Great and wonderful neighborhood resturant. Fine gem indeed. food is great. atmosphere is great for any occasion. Very clean establishment. Fine selection of korean drinks. Open late which is a good thing...because i work late and pizza , microwave foods just does not cut it at all. Um Ma Son is the best!
author: Justin L.

description: Very cute auntie :) Reminds of those aunties I see in Korean drama~ The place is kinda small, but nicee.. and the food is pretty good too :) At least the one I ordered is good, silky tofu with seafood. But it takes pretty long time to serve the food, I understand~~ auntie tried her best :)
author: Marlis T.

description: The woman who runs this charming under-the-radar restaurant is so hospitable and friendly that even if the food was bad, I would have written a nice review. But turns out that not only is she [I'm going to use the word] delightful, but the food is fresh, sizzling, and delicious. Plus, this place stays open late and isn't over crowded. So glad it's in my neighborhood, and thanks for such a tasty meal.
author: Alisa R.

description: Got takeout one night because the dog was with us.  Ordered a Bi Bim Bab and a Duk Mhan Du Guk.  The Bi Bim Bab looked and smelled good but I didn't have a chance to try any since F.C. decided to devour the whole thing in 5 minutes.  My Duk Mhan Du Guk was also very good and there were many dumplings in it.  I'm wondering if it was really hand made dumplings.  It seems like the restaurant is a one woman show.  Her english is not too well and my Korean is non existant other than swear words...which explains why I left without an extra serving of rice.  The portions of the sides seemed a bit small since there were two orders made, but they were good none the less.  I'll come back to try the seafood pancake and kim hcee fried rice.  Another plus is that Um Ma Son is open late hours so many thanks for satisfying my late night food runs.
author: LittleBird 8.

description: I love korean food, so of course when i went here i had expectations. I was craving kimchi chigae that night so i ordered it.
